urn:contentItem:57HW-N1N1-DXH2-60R9-00000-00STOSSEL for January 17, 20132013-01-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:19ZLexisNexisSTOSSEL9:00 PM ESTChuck DeVore, Matt Welch, Suzanna Hopp, Leland Yee, Kennedy, Dan Mitchell, Kevin James, Scott BullockNEWSDomestic011701cb.227STOSSEL for January 17, 2013John Stossel

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JOHN STOSSEL, HOST: Tonight, the showdown between two states -- Texas versus California.

Which is a better place to live?

California has better weather, but that's not going to solve San Bernardino's problem.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: The community is slowly breaking down to nothing.

STOSSEL: Kennedy tried to ask people in city hall what happened.

KENNEDY: Is anyone here?

Hello?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The job prospects are far better in Texas.

STOSSEL: That's true. Texas is growing.

But what about freedom?

In Texas, politicians may grab your land.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: For-profit corporations taking Texans' land.

STOSSEL: But Texans do have the freedom to arm themselves, partly thanks to this woman. Her parents were murdered, but she isn't angry at the guns.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: The guy that did it was a -- a lunatic. That's like being mad at a rabid dog.

STOSSEL: By contrast...

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Check your action.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Buying a handgun in California is no simple task.

STOSSEL: Neither is getting a license to open a business.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Take one, two, or even...

STOSSEL: Texas Versus California -- that's our show tonight.

ANNOUNCER: And now, John Stossel.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

STOSSEL: Twenty percent of you, one in five Americans, lives in either Texas or California. California is the biggest state, Texas is second.

And California is the dream for many Americans. Those beautiful beaches, movie stars, great weather. Its population grew at more than double the national average -- until 1990.

Then, something changed. Last decade, two million more Americans moved out of California than moved in. Many moved to other states like Texas. In the last decade, Texas' pola -- population grew at double the national rate.

And one of those new Texans is Chuck DeVore. He used to be a California politician. Now he's the author of "The Texas Model," which argues that Texas governs better.

Matt Welch of "Reason" magazine also moved from California, but his magazine is still based there.

So why is that?

If you're getting out...

(LAUGHTER)

STOSSEL: -- if California is so bad, why is "Reason" magazine, my favorite magazine, in this horrible state?

MATT WELCH, REASON MAGAZINE: Well, that's, uh, where we've been since 1971 and it informs thinking that gets us a little bit outside of the kind of Beltway Acela, uh, track of thinking.

But it's a -- it's a challenge to be there. Businesses, anyone, to stay in California these days. And you're exactly right to point out, it's a new thing in California. We no longer attract immigrants.

STOSSEL: But, Chuck, there's still something thriving. There's the - - the tech industry, the movie industry. Stuff is happening in...

CHUCK DEVORE, FORMER CALIFORNIA POLITICIAN, AUTHOR OF "THE TEXAS MODEL": Absolutely. California does have a lot of assets. It has Silicon Valley. It does have Hollywood. It has the biotech industry.

The problem is that you can't live off of those narrow bands of industry forever. And what's happening is that because of high taxes, big regulations, uh, unhealthy lawsuit climate and a lot of government spending, people are leaving the state.

STOSSEL: It started in the '90s. Gray Davis said we've got all this cash from the dot-com boom and they -- well, tell me what happened.

WELCH: Well, first of all, he spent the dot-com cash on public sector pension promises and just general spending to everybody.

Even in the last five years of so-called austerity, spending has continued to go up.

STOSSEL: Up beyond inflation and population growth?

WELCH: Yes.

STOSSEL: A new thing, global warming measures ...

WELCH: For high speed rail projects that no one needs, no one wants, yet will cost $68 billion.

STOSSEL: And even Arnold, the Republican, the Terminator, I thought - - really, I fell in love, at one point. I thought here's a politician quoting Milton Friedman. This is a guy who gets it. He'll make it better.

What happened?

DEVORE: Well, what happened was, he helped enact the largest tax increase in U.S. history at the state level in 2009. It was so bad that I resigned as chief Republican whip in the state assembly in protest of the tax increase.

STOSSEL: And he also supported government funds to fund stem cell research. I -- I talked to the guy pushing this once. He was a rich businessman. He -- I said you billionaires could pay for this by yourselves, why is this a government job?

WELCH: It was only a government job because people wanted to stick -- Democrats wanted to stick a thumb in the eye of George W. Bush, which is the same -- their global warming emissions standard. This is an expensive way to say we are not Republicans, we are Californians.

DEVORE: On borrowed money.

STOSSEL: And -- and three, a couple of years later, I read in the papers, oh, this organization has to be revamped. We suspect self-dealing, a conflict of interest. All this money is wasted.

And yet now I read, I balanced the budget, says the governor.

WELCH: Yes, well, they just passed by a ballot initiative, one of the largest, uh, tax increases in the history...

STOSSEL: Tax the rich.

WELCH: They've increased taxes by $50 billion. So, yes, suddenly, it's going to look a lot more balanced there.

But they're also lying. I mean they're talking about a -- revenue projections that will not come true. It's an annual tradition in California, your budget looks balanced in January when you propose it. And then when the revenues actually start coming in, you say, oh, there's a shortfall.

And that shortfall could be $8 billion. It has been as high as $30 billion in recent years. We'll see that happen again.

STOSSEL: All right, Chuck, you've moved to Texas. You say this couldn't be a more interesting lab experiment.

What do you mean?

DEVORE: Well, because the states are so similar, right? You have the -- the biggest state and the second biggest state in population, the second and third biggest state in land mass. They're both demographically very diverse, more similar than different. They both are blessed with quite a few natural resources and a coastline with ports.

And so with everything so similar on the surface, what you have to look at then is why are the results so different. And, of course, the results are different because they're governed differently.

Government, at the state and local level, consumes about a third more of the economy in California than it does in Texas. And that -- with that extra government, you have things like one third of the nation's welfare recipients are in California, even though they only have one eighth of the population.

You have more regulations, more taxes, everything.

STOSSEL: We're -- we have a graph of the -- the welfare recipients, the percentage of households receiving public assistance, much higher in California than the U.S. average and lower than average in Texas.

DEVORE: Absolutely. And that...

STOSSEL: But that just means you're starving poor people.

(LAUGHTER)

DEVORE: Well, not so. The cost of living in Texas is 42 percent less than the cost of living in California. And in point of fact, the U.S. Census Bureau has been criticized by Congress for 20 years for not taking into account cost of living, the fact that different states have different costs of living when it comes to housing and food and clothing.

STOSSEL: And that's relevant when you look at the poverty rate. There -- there was an old poverty rate measure, where Texas lost to California; 16 percent of the people in, uh, California, were in poverty; 17 percent in Texas. But now there's a new measure...

DEVORE: Yes.

STOSSEL: -- that includes the cost of living.

DEVORE: It does include the cost of living and it also includes some government benefits. And with this new measure that came out just one week after the election, what you see is the state with the highest poverty rate in the nation is California, higher even than the District of Columbia.

And -- and that should really be a warning or a caution to progressives who maintain that this big government model is really the path to prosperity.

We argue that it's entirely the opposite, that, in fact, Texas is a model for how America could be better run and there could be more prosperity by having less government.

STOSSEL: There's been more job growth in Texas. Texas gained, in the past 10 years, more than a million jobs. California lost about half a million jobs.

But Paul Krugman says, in the "New York Times," "What's this Texas miracle?" this was when Governor Perry was running for president. "There's no -- it's an un-miracle. The Texas unemployment rate was 8.2 percent."

DEVORE: ... 8.2 percent isn't great, but California, at the time, was 11.8 percent.

WELCH: California has had over 10 percent unemployment every month of Barack Obama's presidency until basically last November.

STOSSEL: And it's still 3 percent higher than Texas.

WELCH: Yes. And it's -- it's been higher, it's -- in California than the national average every month since 1990.

STOSSEL: Now, regulation. You're freer in Texas?

DEVORE: Oh, it's a huge difference. In fact, it was so bad in California that the Democrats allowed this law to be passed that sought to find the cost of regulations on small business.

And when it came out, Governor Schwarzenegger was so embarrassed, he didn't want it to come out.

Finally, we pressured for it to come out. The cost on the average business in California for regulatory compliance is $133,000 per year.

WELCH: The legislature passes, on average, around 900 bills a year, laws. Here you go, governor. Nine -- three a day, or even four a day, when they're in session.

The Texas legislature is it's -- it's in session every two years, is that right?

DEVORE: Every two years for 130, 140 days.

WELCH: Right. They just don't have enough time. And the kind of laws that they're passing in California, they're saying you can't, as a parent, hire a psychiatrist to try to make your kid not gay. I mean it's that level of crazy specificity. We're going to increase ...

STOSSEL: (INAUDIBLE) - But stay on that one for a moment, because I've covered these gay cure psychiatrists. And I think it's nonsense.

WELCH: Sure.

STOSSEL: But it should be your right to pursue something that...

WELCH: It should be your right.

STOSSEL: -- we disagree with.

WELCH: And it shouldn't be the right of the legislature to tell you what kind of things you need to do. And -- and let's increasing the -- the penalties, the fines, for throwing citrus onto a minor league baseball field, seriously, that was a law passed a couple of years ago.

(LAUGHTER)

WELCH: This is the level of the -- of the way the legislature is there...

DEVORE: I didn't vote for it.

(LAUGHTER)

STOSSEL: And if you're one of these big tech companies, Facebook or Google, you could navigate these regulations.

DEVORE: Well, you hire attorneys. You hire, uh, tax experts. You hire compliance experts that help navigate through this bureaucratic maze.

A good example is if you want to build a strip mall. It takes -- just to get permission to break ground and start construction, it takes four to five months, on average, in Texas. It takes four to five years, on average, in California.

And that's one of the things that helps drive up the cost of housing and business complexes and factories in California.

STOSSEL: All right, this is obvious to me, looking from the outside. One works, the other doesn't work as well for its people.

But the politicians are unfazed.

What's that about?

WELCH: Well, part of it is that you have a great home field advantage in California, which is that it's an awful nice place to live, especially along the coast. It's -- it's especially nice if you work in one of the highlight industries.

And then everywhere else in the hinterlands, there's a lot of desperation, poverty and population just leaking and running away.

And so that part on the coast can generate incredible wealth, dynamism. It's fun as hell to work in those industries, right?

But the rest of the state is having a much harder time.

STOSSEL: And they don't have the political clout.

DEVORE: Well, there -- there's another issue, as well, that comes into play in California, in that California is not a right to work state. They have very powerful unions, especially government unions.

They're -- there's no counterpart to that in Texas. People are free to have their associations and the unions aren't there to spend millions and millions of dollars to promote bigger government and higher taxes.

STOSSEL: Hence, more prosperity in Texas.

Thank you, Matt and Chuck.

Coming up, want a free car?

We'll tell you how absurd government benefits get.

But next, gun control in Texas versus California.

Thank you.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Of course he had a gun. This is Texas. Everybody has a gun. My florist has a gun.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

STOSSEL: That scene from the movie "Miss Congeniality" has truth to it.

Want to buy a gun in Texas?

It's easy. No Texas restrictions, just a federal background check. In three days, you can get a gun.

California has lots of restrictions, like waiting periods, an assault weapons ban. After the recent school shooting in Connecticut, California politicians proposed more rules. They want to make hundreds of thousands of previously legal guns illegal. And their owners would have to give them to the government.

By contrast, in Texas, some politicians want to make it easier for teachers to carry guns in school.

What a terrible idea, says California State Senator, Leland Yee.

He joins us from San Francisco.

Welcome.

Also, from...

LELAND YEE, CALIFORNIA STATE SENATOR: Thank you for having me, John.

STOSSEL: Thank you.

From Texas, Suzanna Hopp, who likes the idea of teachers packing heat.

So, Suzanna, why?

SUZANNA HOPP "FROM LUBY'S TO THE LEGISLATURE. ONE WOMAN'S FIGHT AGAINST GUN CONTROL": I guess you could probably say because of my background. I know what it's like to be in a defenseless situation with a crazed shooter that's just there to execute people.

Look, lawyers can protect themselves on the job. Teachers or -- or -- or chiropractors can protect themselves on the jobs.

Why can't our teachers protect themselves on the job?

STOSSEL: And...

HOPP: They're being treated like second class citizens.

STOSSEL: And -- and let's review your background about this. Years ago, you were in a Luby's restaurant when a gunman came in and killed your mom and dad. And that made you want...

HOPP: Well, he killed 23 people. That was the first real mass shooting in this country, uh, back in 1991. And...

STOSSEL: That would...

HOPP: Yes, he was...

STOSSEL: -- that would make a lot of people say I want tougher gun laws. But you say the opposite. And you've written the book, "From Luby's to the Legislature: One Woman's Fight Against Gun Control."

HOPP: Yes, sir.

STOSSEL: So explain your reasoning.

HOPP: At that time, in the state of Texas, you couldn't get a concealed carry permit. They didn't exist.

So I began leaving my gun in my car very dutifully. And, um, my parents and I were having lunch. A madman drove his truck through the window and began executing people.

And I've got to tell you, I -- I can't begin to tell you what it's like to be like a fish in a barrel waiting for it to be your turn.

The only thing that the gun laws did was prevent me and some others in that restaurant from being able to protect ourselves and our families.

STOSSEL: So, Mr. Yee, I assume you strongly disagree with this. Make your case.

YEE: -- I used to work - I used to work in the schools as a psychologist. And I will tell you, I don't know of any teacher or administrator that wants to carry a gun into a classroom into a school. You know, if you start doing that with schools, then why not look at supermarkets?

Why don't we look at hospitals, where there's...

STOSSEL: Fine.

YEE: -- where there's been some gun plays there.

STOSSEL: Fine.

YEE: We...

STOSSEL: Let them all have guns.

YEE: But that's not the way -- that's not the way in which we want to operate in our society \here in California. We're -- we're about educating kids, we're not about telling kids to go and pack guns and shoot 'em up if someone comes, you know, into your schools.

STOSSEL: Suzanna?

HOPP: Wow! We're not talking about the children being able to carry weapons. We're talking about the people that can already carry weapons in the supermarkets, as he said. All we're talking about...

YEE: But, but, but...

HOPP: -- doing is allowing...

YEE: -- but what is the lesson...

HOPP: -- them to carry in a school.

YEE: -- that we adults are saying to kids, that when you are a child and you grow up, to solve your problem, carry a gun. And that is not the life lesson we ought to be teaching...

HOPP: Oh.

YEE: -- children.

HOPP: Oh, heaven's -

(CROSSTALK)

STOSSEL: That's what the...

YEE: It's this society...

STOSSEL: -- that's what the police do.

HOPP: Look, that...

YEE: -- that we have is too violent already.

STOSSEL: The police carry guns...

HOPP: A gun is not a guarantee...

YEE: And -- and that's fine.

HOPP: A gun...

YEE: Police ought to carry a gun. They are there to protect the people of California.

STOSSEL: California has all these gun restrictions, but there are more murders in California per capita than Texas. The -- the gun laws don't work.

YEE: No, no, that's absolutely not true. You know, studies upon studies have demonstrated that the states that have jurisdictions that have, uh, the toughest gun laws are the ones that are the safest per capita.

STOSSEL: That's -- that's nonsense.

YEE: I mean that's just...

(CROSSTALK)

STOSSEL: That's absurd.

HOPP: That is not true. That is absolutely wrong.

STOSSEL: Chicago, Washington, DC, look at -- look at California cities like Oakland.

YEE: All -- all I'm saying is per capita. When -- when you look at the per capita data that it is absolutely true that jurisdictions with the toughest gun control are, in fact, the safest. I -- I mean the reality...

HOPP: No.

YEE: -- in California...

HOPP: That is absolutely false.

STOSSEL: Oakland has the sixth highest murder rate...

(CROSSTALK)

HOPP: Mr. Yee, can I interject something?

STOSSEL: -- murder rate in the nation. Stockton, the 11th highest murder rate ...

HOPP: Mr. Yee, can I ...

STOSSEL: Hang on, Suzanne. I just want to...

HOPP: OK.

STOSSEL: -- contradict what seems to be going against the fact here.

How do you explain Stockton, per capita, and Oakland, the highest murder rate -- among the highest murder rates in the nation?

YEE: No, what -- what -- you know, what I'm saying is that if you look at the entire state, if you look at the entire jurisdiction, that's what we're talking about. You -- you can't look at, you know, specific, you know, individual cities and so on, because that, of course, is -- is...

STOSSEL: Well, I think this is the data...

YEE: -- it's going to give you a lot bit of bias.

STOSSEL: -- from the whole state, but...

YEE: But if you look across...

STOSSEL: Suzanna?

HOPP: I'd like to ask Mr. Yee a question. Mr. Yee, can you name one single place in the United States where one of these mass shootings has occurred where guns were allowed?

Because if guns are the problem, why haven't we seen these mass shootings at the dreaded gun show that you all are trying to make illegal or NRA conventions?

YEE: Look, look, you know, Olympia...

HOPP: If guns are the problem...

YEE: -- you know, let me show you ...

HOPP: -- you're talking about the places...

YEE: In...

HOPP: -- where there are thousands of guns in the hands of -- of law- abiding citizens, yet we only see...

YEE: In -- in -- in the...

HOPP: -- these mass shootings at places...

YEE: -- in the Columbine shooting...

HOPP: -- where guns are not allowed.

YEE: -- there were armed guards there. And that did not stop those young individuals from coming into Columbine and shooting and slaughtering individuals.

HOPP: What -- what did stop it?

YEE: That's all I'm saying, that -- that...

HOPP: What did stop it?

YEE: -- just having a gun is not going to stop all these other individuals, uh, coming into a school, coming into a playground...

HOPP: I'll tell you what...

YEE: -- and shooting our children.

HOPP: -- it will stop.

YEE: We've got to look at...

HOPP: It absolutely will stop them.

YEE: -- other ways of dealing with...

HOPP: And, in fact...

YEE: -- this particular problem.

HOPP: -- in Texas -- in Texas, we already have several schools where the administrators, you mentioned earlier that no teachers and no administrators would want to carry.

On the contrary, we have several teachers and administrators that already do carry in some school districts.

YEE: Well, you know, I think...

(CROSSTALK)

STOSSEL: The law in Texas allows the district to...

(CROSSTALK)

STOSSEL: -- make its own decisions.

HOPP: They don't have law enforcement...

YEE: You're always going to find one...

HOPP: -- handy.

YEE: -- or two administrators here and there. But overall, when you ask the question, teachers, do you want to pack guns going into your classroom, the answer, resoundingly, is no. No teacher goes to...

STOSSEL: Well, then, you know...

YEE: -- uh, to college to be a teacher...

STOSSEL: -- politicians don't have to get involved.

(CROSSTALK)

YEE: -- to say I'm going to be carrying a gun.

STOSSEL: If the teacher doesn't want to...

(CROSSTALK)

STOSSEL: Nobody is forcing teachers to carry a gun. Why do you politicians have to get involved...

HOPP: That's right.

STOSSEL: -- and say the teacher who wants to, thinks it makes her safer, she may not?

HOPP: Yes.

YEE: No. If you happen to be a teacher, and you go and purchase a gun and you want to go through the background checks and so on, ultimately you're going to have a gun.

STOSSEL: You can have it in a school in California? It's OK with you?

YEE: No. Absolutely not. You're not going to carry a gun in the school. We don't allow students to carry guns. Why are we going to let teachers carry guns? (INAUDIBLE) --

(CROSSTALK)

HOPP: You're making it a killing zone. Mr. Yee, you're making them killing zones.

YEE: No, schools are a gun-free zone. We're not --

(CROSSTALK)

HOPP: Yes, and that's exactly where bad guys, where they want to rack up a big body bag count is the gun-free zone. That's where they rack up big body bag counts. That's where they go.

(CROSSTALK)

STOSSEL: We're not going to solve this in this show. Thank you both. I have to stop you, Suzanna Hopp, Leland Yee.

Coming up, what happens when your town goes bankrupt. And what else can we learn comparing Texas and California?

(MUSIC PLAYING)

(MUSIC PLAYING, "HOTEL CALIFORNIA")

STOSSEL: But people do leave Hotel California these days because they can't pay the bills. Four California cities have now declared bankruptcy, Stockton the biggest and San Bernardino. The result isn't pretty.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The community's slowly breaking down to nothing.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: (INAUDIBLE) empty, lots that are empty, parking lots that are empty.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Well, people are suffering and people are going through, you know, and there's no opportunity, there's nothing. It's like a ghost town here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

STOSSEL: Three-fourths of the city's money went to what they call public safety. That means unionized cops and firemen. Politicians promised them much more money than the town had. So do the people in San Bernardino realize that's the reason the town went belly up? No.

This show's special correspondent, Kennedy, went there to ask and heard that even bankruptcy, people like cops and firefighters.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Well, we were not the ones that (INAUDIBLE) the problem.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Firefighters are heroes, cops are heroes. So who's to say what's too much and what's not?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I don't blame anyone in particular. It's just a matter of things that happened over the course of years.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

STOSSEL: This next man is in the prison guards' union. California prison guards make $66,000 a year before benefits.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The people of California, we gave them so much, you know, and we're not getting anything back.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Because we give it all to the unions.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: No, we don't.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Oh, yes. We absolutely do.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I pay union dues. No, we don't.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: No, you pay the union dues; we pay for your pensions.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Well, of course.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

STOSSEL: Of course. And the pensions make that $66,000 pay close to $100,000. They're big in California.

KENNEDY: Oh, yes, and the firefighters in San Bernardino, their salary has doubled. And now they make $150,000 a year.

STOSSEL: But people weren't upset at them.

KENNEDY: Well, I would say ignorance is bliss. But no one there seemed very happy. So maybe that adage doesn't hold true for San Bernardino.

STOSSEL: Well, Kennedy thought the mayor's office would be a place to go to learn more about what caused the bankruptcy. So she tried that.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KENNEDY: That's San Bernardino City Hall. It's a really nice building, and it looks really expensive, which might be part of the problem. Let's go get some answers.

There must be people in there working seven days a week to solve these problems.

Mayor's office, 6.

I walk down an empty hallway looking for the mayor -- looking for anyone. I felt like I was in a horror movie. It was creepy.

Is anyone here?

Hello?

So I found an empty conference room and decided I would take over as mayor.

All right, everyone, thanks for coming. It's really great to have you here. I'm the acting mayor.

There's not a lot happening. Does anyone have anything that I should be looking at on the rundown, the agenda, show of hands? All right. Not all at once. It's a busy day, San Bernardino. We have a lot of problems, lot of people out of work, lot of businesses with shuttered doors. And I don't hear any answers from any of you.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

STOSSEL: All right. They were supposed to be in the office that day.

KENNEDY: Yes, the mayor's office is supposed to be fully stocked on Fridays. There are other agencies that take Friday furloughs.

STOSSEL: The city's less safe, the city attorney told residents, go home, lock your doors and load your guns.

KENNEDY: By the way, he was there and he would not talk to us.

STOSSEL: One union blamed the mayor and former city manager that -- for spending money on a downtown movie theater.

KENNEDY: Yes, the movie theater is nice, but it's nothing compared to the $45.8 million deficit that the City of San Bernardino is running. And by the way, when they filed for bankruptcy, they had $150,000 in the city bank account.

STOSSEL: San Bernardino politicians said we didn't see it coming. How could they -- they owed $46 million. They had $100,000 in the bank.

KENNEDY: Yes. And they have payments that they're required to pay into CalPERS, $1.8 million a month. And they didn't see that coming, with $150K in the bank.

STOSSEL: And San Bernardino tried to raise money through fees, like expensive parking tickets, traffic tickets.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Look at all the money we just paid, more than $400-$500 on a -- just a speeding ticket. And they're going bankrupt?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KENNEDY: What he didn't tell you is he was going 90 in a school zone.

STOSSEL: So he should pay. But it's not going to cover all these pension obligations.

KENNEDY: Nothing's going to cover these pensions obligations, not in San Bernardino, not in Stockton, not in Vallejo, not in Compton, not in any of these other cities in California that are simply failing.

STOSSEL: Finding a silver lining, I hear that there's more civil society perking up. Volunteers are doing park maintenance, working at the animal shelter, replacing broken street lights. Neighborhood Watch associations are starting to blossom to police neighborhoods. That's good.

KENNEDY: Yes, and they want their city back. So they're taking it themselves. And it just goes to show the private solution is always better.

STOSSEL: And it's what they're going to have to go when the government has spent all the money.

Thank you, Kennedy.

Next, we take this same problem that bankrupted San Bernardino and see what it does to the whole state. It's not pretty.

STOSSEL: California is paradise for government workers. Per person, Texas actually has more of them. But California pays better and gives out such generous retirement benefits that California will probably go broke.

Some 50-year-old retirees were promised they can collect forever, well, until they die, but actually after that too, because their spouse may collect after they die. And the money just isn't there.

Dan Mitchell studies state pension problems nationally for the CATO Institute. Kevin James is running to be mayor of Los Angeles. So before we get to what Kevin discovered in Los Angeles, how bad is this? These people want to be responsible, I would think.

DAN MITCHELL, CATO INSTITUTE: I'm not sure they want to be responsible. I think the politicians want to get reelected and the state government workers want to get as much as they can before the whole house of cards comes tumbling down.

The problem is, is California is Greece, the Greece of America. There are too many people riding in the wagon, not enough people pulling the wagon. Now they've raised taxes. So you're going to see the productive people leaving the state and more and more people living off the government, voting for more government.

But sooner or later, nobody is there to pay the bills.

STOSSEL: All right. They pay the workers more in California, but California has a higher cost of living.

MITCHELL: It does, but even with all that, that doesn't justify the difference between, say, $50,000 average wage salary versus $70,000 in California. California is pricing itself out of the market.

STOSSEL: Plus the benefits, which go into this fund, called CalPERS, and they assumed for years an 8 percent rate of return. Oh, we're going to make so much money. Now they've just lowered it from 7.75 percent to 7.5 percent, like that's responsible.

Where do they get off thinking that they can make that rate of return? Why is that acceptable?

MITCHELL: I'm going to assume tonight I'm going to party with Victoria's Secret supermodels. I don't think it's going to happen, though. And likewise, I don't think that CalPERS is going to meet those targets that it set.

And if they don't meet those targets, it means they're an unfunded liability, which is huge already, will become enormous. And they simply won't be able to pay it in the same way that Greece hasn't been able to pay its bills.

STOSSEL: All right. And, Kevin, let's talk about Los Angeles. You're running for mayor, so we won't go into your campaign specifically. But one thing you told me that astounded me is that the Los Angeles City council-members are paid $178,000 per year?

KEVIN JAMES (R), LOS ANGELES MAYORIAL CANDIDATE: They are the highest paid legislative body in the nation, John. You know, we just had a councilwoman that -- Janice Hahn went to Congress, the House of Representatives, and she has to take a cut in pay. They make more money that United States senators for a Los Angeles City Council.

STOSSEL: Los Angeles, each councilman is given a car?

JAMES: Well, each councilman, I'll tell you something else that really gets Angelenos, they get a car that has a license plate that says "exempt." So they can park in meters and they don't get tickets.

And in Los Angeles, our parking tickets are through the roof.

And just as you were talking about in the last segment with all of these fines and fees that they keep wanting to take from people that come to Los Angeles, it's not good for business. It chases customers away from our city and from our local businesses into neighboring communities, where they don't get abused by city hall.

STOSSEL: One hundred seventy eight thousand dollars per year in Los Angeles versus in Dallas $37,000, San Antonio $1,400.

JAMES: Well, those are part-time -- those are part-time city councils. In Los Angeles...

STOSSEL: But they seem to get it done.

JAMES: ... they're a full-time council.

STOSSEL: It's not like Los Angeles is...

JAMES: Who gets -- of course they do.

STOSSEL: ... is so well-governed.

Dan, put this in perspective nationally. Is it a mindset in California that says politicians just work magic and need to be compensated?

MITCHELL: I think what happened is during the boom years in California, for decades after World War II, people were just pouring into the state. There was a lot of opportunity, great climate.

And, sure, government can charge a little bit more to get the great climate in California. But at some point you hit the tipping level, where all of a sudden it's just too expensive to create jobs. It's too expensive to finance a bloated workforce. It's too expensive to maintain all of these pensions.

But by the time you've reached that level, if more than 50 percent of the voters in your state are somehow riding on the wagon, are either government welfare beneficiaries, government workers, or the retired living off government, how do you ever change?

And that's what makes me so pessimistic. A beautiful state that I think is being ruined by big government.

STOSSEL: Thank you, Dan Mitchell, and Kevin James.

So far tonight in the battle between Texas and California, Texas is winning. But when we return, a reason Texans should prefer California.

STOSSEL: Texas is less likely to go broke than California. And they have fewer stupid rules, probably. They do have less total regulation. But Texas has plenty of control-freak politicians. And as a result, your property may be safer in California than Texas, so says Scott Bullock from the Institute for Justice.

So why is your property not as safe in Texas?

SCOTT BULLOCK, INSTITUTE FOR JUSTICE: Well, Texas has some bad laws with regards to private property rights. Civil forfeiture laws are very aggressive and very potent in Texas, where the government can take your property, even if you have not been convicted or even arrested for a crime. And then the burden is on the property owner to try to get their property back.

STOSSEL: All right. Explain civil forfeiture more. The Institute for Justice, your group, made this video about it. So if police arrest you, prosecutors must prove that you are guilty before they can put you in jail.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: But if police suspect your car was involved in a crime, they can take it, sell it, and in most places pocket the proceeds to pad their budgets. With civil forfeiture, your property is guilty until you prove it innocent to get it back.

And because most state and federal laws allow police and prosecutors to pocket the proceeds, they have a big incentive to pursue profits, not justice. How big? In 1986, the Justice Department's forfeiture fund took in $94 million. Now it has more than a billion.

Citizens are seeing cash, cars, and other property taken away for the flimsiest of reasons. Carrying too much cash? Police can accuse you of selling drugs or laundering money and seize it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

STOSSEL: Come on, just because you have a lot of cash in the car, they can take your car?

BULLOCK: Yes.

STOSSEL: And the cash?

BULLOCK: They can take the car and the cash, and accuse you of either being a drug dealer or laundering money, even if there are no drugs in the car or they have no other reason to suspect you of wrongdoing.

And then the burden shifts...

STOSSEL: How much cash, typically?

BULLOCK: It could be what the police officers considers to be an unusually large amount of cash, which could be as small as $900, $1,200, $2,000. And then the burden shifts to the property owner in Texas to try to get their property back.

Also in Texas...

STOSSEL: And hiring a lawyer to defend yourself would cost you much more than $1,200.

BULLOCK: Absolutely. So most people just give up, and because it's a civil proceeding, the government can win by default. And that's the way many of these cases turn out.

STOSSEL: You have one client whose truck was lost, because he loaned it to somebody else who drove drunk.

BULLOCK: That's right. And this happens all the time where people who are wholly innocent of wrongdoing can still face the loss of their property.

Also in Texas, police and prosecutors keep 90 percent of the proceeds from forfeiture, giving them a very direct and a very perverse incentive to go out and try to take as much property as possible.

STOSSEL: In one state, chief of police bought a margarita-maker for his office with the funds. California isn't great on this either.

BULLOCK: It's not great, but it is better than Texas. In California, police and prosecutors only keep 65 percent, giving them still certainly a bad and perverse incentive, but not as bad. And at least in California, the burden is on the government to try to prove that you did something wrong, unlike in Texas where the burden is on the property owner.

STOSSEL: And the Institute says the best states for protecting property -- Maine, North Dakota, Vermont.

Let's move on to eminent domain, another property issue. Texas passed -- after Kelo, took this woman's house, Texas passed a constitutional amendment saying you can't do that. Texas should be good.

BULLOCK: That's right. Texas does have much better eminent domain law than they originally did. The legislature passed some laws after the wake of Kelo, but they made a bunch of exemptions in the law, including exemption for the Cowboys Stadium where the government there took over 100 pieces of property to build the monolith to the Dallas Cowboys.

Ironically enough now, California is better about eminent domain, not because of their laws, but because California is broke. And one of the things that the state did in order to try to improve their finances is to abolish redevelopment agencies throughout the state. And those were the main abusers of eminent domain.

So this is an instance where the fiscal crisis in California has actually led to something that better protects property owners.

STOSSEL: By de-power -- by defunding the government bullies, they steal fewer people's property.

BULLOCK: That's exactly right. Ironically enough.

STOSSEL: Licensing rules. This is what it takes to start a business. In Texas, shampooers have to get a license?

BULLOCK: Texas is one of five states that require shampooers to be licensed. They have to spend over $100 a year on a license. They have to pass two exams, something that you and I and probably most of the audience here successfully did this morning, you have to pass exams in Texas in order to become a licensed shampooer. So that's ridiculous and there's no justification for it.

STOSSEL: To coach sports, you have to be a licensed teacher?

BULLOCK: Texas one of the few states that require that as well. You have to go to college for four years in order to coach any sport in Texas. Texas takes -- Texans take their sports very seriously. This is just a barrier to entry into a legitimate occupation.

STOSSEL: Commercial fishermen have to pay almost $5,000 in fees. But bad as Texas is, California, in licensing, is worse.

BULLOCK: California is worse. California has very draconian occupational licensing laws, but Texas is 17th in the nation in their burdensome occupational licensing laws. So it's certainly better than California, but there is a lot of room for improvement in Texas when it comes to licensing.

STOSSEL: Thank you, Scott Bullock. At least we found some things where California does OK. And coming up, one more thing we should be very grateful to California for.

STOSSEL: Thank you, California. America needs you. We need you the way we needed the Soviet Union, as a model of failure, to warn us what happens if we listen to those who say government does it better.

The USSR died about 20 years ago. Many of you forgot its horrors. You young people may not even know them. That's why I'm grateful that we have not just California, but Illinois and Connecticut to remind us of what power-mad politicians do.

OK. That's not fair, American states aren't murderous dictatorships. And, another difference, if you live in a big government state, you can move, vote with your feet. I did.

I grew up in Illinois. It was a nice state, except in the winter. But gradually its politicians gave away its future. They increased pay and pensions to government workers to the point that soon Illinois won't have money for much of anything else.

I moved to New York City, which is no political paradise either, but what could I do? This is where the big TV news jobs were, and still are. And at least New York's promises to unions may not bankrupt us too soon.

And I could move again. I would still be stuck with federal law, but it's an advantage to live in a country that has 50 states. Each can be a laboratory of democracy. If one gets it right, I can move there.

A group called the Free State Project invites you to move to New Hampshire to help create liberty in our lifetime. It's too early to see how that one works out.

But I'm glad that we have states so I don't have to leave my country to escape its worst laws. In Europe, I would. French actor Gerard Depardieu just moved to Belgium to escape France's proposed 75 percent tax on rich people.

Years ago high taxes in Britain drove David Bowie to move to Switzerland, and Rod Stewart to Los Angeles. Wait, that's in California, I wonder if he's now going to move back. Oh, he has. In 2010 he moved his family back to England, though he doesn't claim taxes were the reason.

Americans who want to escape high taxes can move to one of these states: Alaska, Florida, New Hampshire, Nevada, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Washington, and Wyoming. All have no state income tax. And, surprise, those states create more jobs.

It's no surprise, actually. Without an income tax, they were forced to limit the growth of their governments, so they did. Every state has schools, social service programs, prisons, those states find a way to fund those for less. Then they reap benefits.

Last decade those nine states gained population from other states. They increased jobs by 4.9 percent; jobs in the rest of the states declined by 2.6 percent. Competition between neighboring states also deters state politicians from indulging in all their whims.

New Hampshire's lack of an income tax has kept Vermont's politicians from going completely crazy. The existence of Arizona and Nevada nearby deter California's legislators from going crazy.

Well, actually, they still go crazy, despite so many people moving from California to Nevada and Arizona. But it's good that we have places like Texas. Smaller government there means growth and a gradual increase in prosperity, while California shrinks. I hope the rest of the country watches and learns from that.

That's our show, see you next week.

urn:contentItem:5V27-8ST1-DYRW-R2G7-00000-00Strains show in job market2018-12-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:19ZLexisNexis/EDITORIAL/CONTENT/SCMP/ECONOMYnws focus 01.pglPg.4Strains show in job market

It's a frustrating time for ­furniture makers like Jason Chen, whose meagre profits have fallen victim to the US-China trade war. But the dark cloud of that conflict has one silver lining: good technical workers are no longer so hard to find.

Chen, who manages two ­factories that make wooden frames for sofas and tables in Jiangsu and Zhejiang provinces, has not had to lay off any of his 600 staff despite the blow to his business. He was fortunate to have a mostly independent supply chain, but still had to scale down the workforce in the smaller ­factory and move them to the bigger facility to save costs.

In late October, he hired two experienced sample makers laid off by other factories. Their salary demands were "not too high", ­because there were few other jobs to be had.

However, not everyone is fortunate and capable enough to spread their risk between different baskets.

"If between half and 70 per cent of one's business comes from the US market, then it's hard to survive," Chen said. "I estimate that small manufacturers with fewer than 200 employees will ­disappear after January."

That is when American tariffs on US$200 billion worth of ­imports, including furniture, were initiallyexpected to rise to 25 per cent from an initial 10 per cent rate levied in September. But after President Xi Jinping and his US counterpart, Donald Trump, met on December 1, the tariff increase was put on hold until March while Washington and Beijing continue trade negotiations.

The trade war has created an extra, unexpected burden for ­Beijing: to maintain enough jobs as the economy slows. This is ­particularly true, given the extra hardship they face, for private ­sector firms, which account for about 80 per cent of all jobs and 90 per cent of new jobs, according to government data.

Last year, China was the largest exporter of furniture to the United States, shipping US$11.3 billion worth. The tariffs have had a chilling effect on the 6,000-plus furniture manufacturers, most of which are privately owned, and brought down the number of employees in the industry to about 1.1 million at the end of October, the lowest figure in three years, ­according to official data.

The top leadership knows well the importance of having enough jobs. In the statement that ­followed the latest meeting of the policymaking Politburo this month, stabilising employment was mentioned first, before efforts to manage finance, trade and market expectations.

On the surface, the job market seems well under control. The ­official survey-basedunemployment rate released by the ­National Bureau of Statistics ­remained unchanged at 4.9 per cent in September and October before falling slightly to 4.8 per cent last month, while the average jobless rate in 31 major cites was even lower, at 4.7 per cent in ­November - compared with the global average of 5.7 per cent ­reported by the International ­Labour Organisation.

According to the Ministry of Human Resources and Social ­Security, the government created more than 12 million new jobs in urban areas during the first 10 month of this year, achieving its annual target two months early.

But the overall numbers hid a stark difference in the available supply of labour between small and large firms. For private enterprises with a workforce of less than 100, job supply fell below demand in the third quarter, whereas large firms offered an average of 2.87 jobs for every applicant.

Using data from April to ­September from recruitment website 51jobs, Song Xuetao, an economist at Tianfeng Securities, found that about 2 million vacancies disappeared over the six months and recruitment by private firms with 50 to 500 staff fell more sharply than for state-owned enterprises.

"Under the current economy, small and micro firms contribute 80 per cent of all jobs, around 70 per cent of technological innovation, more than 60 per cent of [gross domestic product] and more than 50 per cent of tax revenues," said Dong Dezhi, an analyst at Guoxin Securities. "Turning around the businesses of small and medium [sized]enterprisesto help job creation is where we can make a breakthrough to stabilise the job market."

Beijing has become restless as the trade war continues. In mid-November, the State Council drafted a policy paper containing proposals ranging from refunding the unemployment insurance contributions of companies that do not lay off staff to giving subsidies to jobless 16-to-24-year-olds. Local governments were ordered to draft their own proposals by this month.

Beijing also called for local governments to increase financial support for entrepreneurs and small private enterprises - the main driver of urban employment in China - by offering government-guaranteed loans of 150,000 to 3 million yuan (HK$3.4 million).

The government is also encouraging laid-off workers to set up their own small businesses. Migrant workers in particular are being given subsidies, tax breaks and other financial incentives to return home and start their own companies.

Since the early 2000s, almost all new jobs in China have been created in cities. The labour market is facing challenges from two ends: industrial consolidation and automation reduce the job supply, while a shrinking workforce, rising labour costs and declining job market participation - driven down mainly by women leaving the labour force - all contribute to depressing the demand for jobs.

But thanks to a surge in service jobs, particularly at small companies, urban employment growth has remained relatively stable even as the economy has slowed

"Both basic and advanced services are contributing to this [jobs] growth, but it's the basic services industries that have been the stronger growth driver in most ­recent years," read a recent report from the Conference Board, a New York-based research firm.

"They have become the catch basin for the lower-skilled ­segment of the workforce, absorbing a large share of less skilled workers, presumably transitioning from legacy sectors. Without the continued job growth from micro-enterprises, urban employment would in fact be ­contracting."

The question is: can Beijing help small service providers keep creating jobs? Some recent figures are of concern. The employment sub-index in theNovember ­CaixinPurchasing Managers' ­Index for the service sector, which mainly covers small private firms, showed that the workforce in the service industry grew mildly in the past two months but could not offset downsizing in the manufacturing sector.

A monthly survey from Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing's Cheung Kong Graduate School of Business gauging more than 300 alumni - mostly executives at private companies - indicated that their plans to recruit staff had plunged over the past two months to the worst level in six years.

In the export sector, hiring demand fell by more than half in the third quarter, according to the China Institute for Employment Research at Renmin University of China in Beijing, which works with job hunting site Zhaopin to produce a quarterly report.

The supply of new jobs declined even more in coastal cities such as Ningbo and Suzhou, which rely heavily on international trade.

Meanwhile, job postings in the internet and IT sector, which had been fertile ground for well-paid service jobs, fell by more than half in the third quarter from a year earlier.

A senior executive at an internet firm of about 1,000 employees, who preferred not to be identified, said she had raised performance targets to improve productivity, even though she had not frozen headcounts or laid off staff. She noted that many of the jobseekers knocking on her door came from the peer-to-peer lending industry, in which hundreds of platforms have collapsed since July after the government tightened regulations.

In October, reports of big tech firms such as Huawei, Tencent and Alibaba - which owns the Post - freezing recruitment shocked the public. The companies later denied the reports, but some smaller tech firms are scaling back operations.

Juanpi.com, an e-commerce platform, has been demanding employees work overtime since last year. Video platform ­Kuaishou recently stopped hiring through headhunters, according to a recruiter source. Meituan ­Dianping, a Hong Kong-listed online platform that generates most of its revenue from food delivery, this year reported about 250 job cuts - 0.5 per cent of its workforce.

"Salary is a priority, but many candidates for tech start-ups care a lot about job stability at the ­moment," said Eva Li, a Beijing-based headhunter who helps tech companies find engineers.

For now, the transition from industrial (secondary) jobs to service sector (tertiary) ones appears smooth, partly because a strong economy over the past few years has created many entry-level, low-skilled jobs - such as in package or food delivery. But boosting entrepreneurship to offset demographic challenges requires consistent government support, which is easier said than done, according to Gao Yuan, an economist from the Conference Board.

"As growth continues to slow, it will become increasingly difficult for the government to maintain the balancing act between upholding employment stability and advancing structural ­reforms," Gao said.

One risk factor for employment stability is the rise in worker protests in service industries, according to China Labour Bulletin (CLB), a Hong Kong-based non-governmental organisation that tracks labour unrest.

Of 1,444 incidents recorded during the first 10 months of this year, 238 were in retail and 224 in transport, which is dominated by online services such as ride-sharing giant Didi and Meituan ­Dianping.

"One indirect effect of the slowdown in manufacturing that may, in the coming months, be exacerbated by the Sino-US trade war is the funnelling of laid-off factory workers into low-paid, insecure and often dangerous jobs in emerging service industries. It is these industries that are now ­increasingly the focus of worker protests in China," CLB warned.

"As these new businesses absorb more and more of the ­workforce laid off from the manufacturing sector, we would expect to see a greater number of strikes and protests over low pay, lack of benefits, long working hours and lack of job security."

China's private sector, the driving force behind the country's economic miracle of the last 40 years, is struggling amid the trade war with the United States and the government's campaign to reduce national debt. This report by Sidney Leng is the fourth in a series detailing the challenges that private companies face and outlining Beijing's attempts to address them.

urn:contentItem:5XCX-B1P1-JCMN-Y122-00000-00Streaming AI for visa applications is biased, rights group claims2019-10-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:19ZLexisNexisStreaming AI for visa applications is biased, rights group claimsBobbyH

Oct 30, 2019( IT Pro: http://www.itpro.co.uk Delivered by Newstex) A streaming algorithm[1] used by the Home Office to filter UK visa applications is to be the subject of a legal case launched by immigration rights campaigners. The legal challenge will look at how this artificial intelligence[2] program affects immigration policy decisions, which the campaigners say is a racially biased and unlawful system. The challenge is being brought by the Joint Council for the Welfare of Immigrants and a human rights group called Foxglove.

The two organisations are seeking a judicial review to find out what the algorithm is and what it is used for. Foxglove formed in 2015 as an organisation to stand up to big tech companies and governments that use digital services that harm or mistreat the general public. It is made up of lawyers, tech experts and communications specialists and takes its name from a European wildflower (digitalis sp) that can both harm and cure. The Home office has declined a request to explain how the software works, according to Foxglove's operational director Martha Dark. She said that it is "hiding behind an immigration exemption in the Freedom of Information Act"."Remember Theresa May's racist migration policy[3] that put 'Go Home' vans on our streets and gave us the Windrush scandal - if you thought it was history, think again," Dark wrote on a fundraising page[4]. "The hostile environment continues. And it is now going digital. "We've discovered a secret technology that basically works as a digital hostile environment. We need your help to expose it - and to take the Home Office to court." According to Foxglove, the Home Office is using a "secretive algorithm", described as a digital "streaming tool", to sift visa applications. The algorithm scans applications and directs them into a fast lane, denoted by the colour green, a slow lane which is yellow, or a "full digital pat-down" which is red. "They've given a shadowy, computer-driven process the power to affect someone's chances of getting a visa," Dark said. "And as best as we can tell, the machine is using problematic and biased criteria[5], like nationality, to choose which 'stream' you get in. People from rich white countries get Speedy Boarding; poorer people of colour get pushed to the back of the queue." The campaigners say the algorithm may be discriminating on the basis of crude characteristics like nationality or age, rather than assessing applicants fairly, on the merits. IT Pro contacted the Home Office which said the tool "complies fully with the relevant legislation under the Equalities Act 2010". "We have always used processes that enable UK Visas and Immigration to allocate cases in an efficient way," a Home Office spokesperson said. "The streaming tool is only used to allocate applications, not to decide them." Gracie Bradley, Liberty policy and campaigns manager, said that decisions which impact people's rights should be made by people and not machines. "It's vital immigration decisions are fully transparent[6] so people can understand and challenge them - opaque, unaccountable algorithms make that impossible," she told IT Pro. "It's especially concerning this tool appears to stream people based on nationality - a recipe for discriminatory decision-making[7]." urn:contentItem:5YY9-Y0M1-F021-61PV-00000-00Streaming giants tighten control on film industry;Apple's deal to secure the exclusive rights of the latest Tom Hanks movie represents another shift in the power of the streamers2020-05-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:19ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYVersion:2Streaming giants tighten control on film industryApple's deal to secure the exclusive rights of the latest Tom Hanks movie represents another shift in the power of the streamersBy Michael Cogley, Technology Correspondent

Two decades ago, Marc Randolph made an offer to Blockbuster CEO John Antioco that he thought he couldn't refuse; buy Netflix for $50m (£41m).

Antioco couldn't help but snigger. Randolph, who co-founded Netflix along with Reed Hastings, said it was one of his lowest moments of his career: "You fly to Blockbuster, try and sell the business, and they laugh at you."

Today, Netflix is worth $197bn while Blockbuster has become a long-forgotten name after it filed for bankruptcy in 2010.

Nowadays, no one is underestimating the importance of streaming giants. Apple, Netflix and Amazon are all trying to get a slice of industry, and the coronavirus pandemic seems to have sped up their efforts.

On Tuesday, it was announced that Tom Hanks' WWII movie Greyhound will be released on Apple TV Plus, instead of in cinemas by Sony.

Deadline reported the deal will be the iPhone-maker's biggest commitment to a feature length film to date.

An uneven blow

The changed release is largely due to lockdown measures globally, with social distancing rules hammering the film sector as badly as any other industry.

"We don't know when it's going to recover and we don't know when people are going to be able to sit next to each other again," says Tom Harrington, a senior TV analyst at Enders Analysis.

"It's not going to be like flicking a switch and people will just go out sit side by side in theatres and cinemas."

Cinema attendance in the UK has enjoyed a rise in recent years, reaching a high of 177 million in 2018 before dipping slightly to 176 million last year, according to industry group Cinema First. In 2019, a star-studded year that included Joker, Knives Out, and Avengers: End Game drove an annual box office take of in excess of £1.25bn.

Cinemas have also caught the attention of Jeff Bezos' Amazon, which is reportedly in talks to buy US chain AMC Theatres. The theatre chain operates both AMC and Carmike in the US as well as Odeon cinemas in the UK.

AMC is currently valued at around $475m, while Amazon is worth $1.22 trillion. As Harrington says, the price of buying AMC would be practically "nothing".

"Cinemas are obviously going to take a massive hit from the pandemic but at the same time you're going to have all these streaming services that are largely unaffected," he says.

"Amazon is probably better off as a result of the coronavirus, elsewhere Netflix had an amazing quarter last quarter and the next is going to be even better. Basically the only place you can release a film right now is direct to the consumer digitally."

A new role for cinema

Like many industries, the pandemic is likely to cause widespread change in cinemas.

Boutique picture houses have been on the rise for some time looking to push the idea of cinema going as an "experience".

According to Michael Hewson, chief markets analyst at CMC Markets, pursuing such a model may be crucial to their revival.

"Cinemas kind of have to go for a more premium experience," he says. "Now that's going to be problematic in the short-term because first and foremost they will need to spend quite a bit of money on it but more importantly with higher unemployment there are going to be fewer people able to afford it."

Hewson says that regulators will watch any such deal such as Amazon's proposed move for AMC.

"Regulators might have a concern about having big tech dominate large wholesale industries," he says.

However, it appears that big tech companies have already proliferated much of the film industry.

Streaming giants move in

Netflix struck an enormous production deal with Shepperton Studios in 2019 to set up a permanent production base. Reed Hastings' giant enterprise is also pushing to acquire the famous Egyptian Theatre on Hollywood Boulevard, an undoubtedly symbolic acquisition.

Elsewhere, Disney - the king of the cinematic box office - has made impressive inroads into the streaming world as well, breaking 50 million subscribers in months.

At a time when projectors are switched off, movie makers may be forced into striking new deals rapidly. MGM is waiting to push out the latest James Bond film No Time to Die, which had been slated for release in early April. The production release has been pushed to November in the hope of gaining a proper run at box office.

Elsewhere, films that skip the big screen will be allowed to contend for Oscars this year, the Academy said in a significant rule change forced by the coronavirus pandemic.

Debate has raged in recent years over Oscar contenders produced by streaming giants such as Netflix, including last year's The Irishman and 2018's Roma.

Until now, the films have been shown at theaters for brief windows before moving online, in order to remain eligible.

If streaming giants have their way, the academy's rules will remain long after the pandemic is over.

urn:contentItem:5RWB-78M1-DXY4-X02Y-00000-00Streaming Soon: A Fight Over AT&T, Time Warner, and the Future of TV2018-03-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:19ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYStreaming Soon: A Fight Over AT&T, Time Warner, and the Future of TVCecilia Kang

The Justice Department’s case to block AT&T’s $85 billion merger with Time Warner is set for trial next week, in one of the most anticipated antitrust battles in years.

WASHINGTON — How you watch “Game of Thrones” and CNN is about to have its day in court.

The Justice Department’s bid to block AT&T’s $85 billion merger with Time Warner is set to head to trial next week, in one of the most anticipated antitrust battles in years.

The deal, if approved, would create a media giant that combines AT&T’s nationwide mobile and satellite distribution networks with Time Warner’s huge collection of popular movies and television offerings, including “Game of Thrones” on HBO, news on CNN and college and professional basketball on TNT. The central question of the trial: Would that combination hurt consumers or help them?

How the judge rules in the case has the potential to shape the fast-changing business of video, as consumers increasing turn to streaming services instead of traditional cable TV. AT&T, a nationwide satellite TV and wireless provider, argues that pairing up with a major content company is necessary to compete against the reach and resources of tech giants like Netflix and Amazon. But the Justice Department says the deal would hurt upstart streaming services and lead to higher prices for consumers.

The decision will frame the competition among Silicon Valley, Hollywood and Madison Avenue, while also establishing what kinds of corporate mergers — in the media industry and beyond — will be permitted in the years to come.

“This court case is so important it is hard to know where to start,” said Amy Yong, a research analyst at the investment firm Macquarie. “This case is at the heart of what we do in our everyday lives.”

The Justice Department’s move to block the deal in November took Wall Street and the entertainment industry by surprise. Many executives and lawyers thought President Trump’s administration would usher in a hands-off approach to antitrust enforcement, despite Mr. Trump’s criticism of the deal on the campaign trail.

Instead, the Justice Department, under its antitrust chief Makan Delrahim, moved aggressively, demanding the sale of major parts of the businesses before a deal could go through. AT&T responded by suggesting that Mr. Delrahim’s decision was politically motivated and not based on established antitrust law.

In recent weeks, though, the judge overseeing the case, Richard Leon of the United States District Court of the District of Columbia, has rejected   moves by AT&T to inject politics into the arguments.

Unless the two sides settle — and there have been no signs of that happening — the trial is expected to showcase two starkly different visions of the country’s video future. Drama is also in the cards: Executives from AT&T and Time Warner, as well as competing cable, satellite, tech and media firms, are expected to take the stand over the course of several weeks — and possibly reveal details about the inner workings of the industry.

The Justice Department argues that the merged company’s combination of distribution and content would give it too much leverage in negotiations with the rest of the industry. It also says that the new company would demand higher licensing fees from other cable and satellite firms for what the government calls “must-watch” programming. Those higher charges would immediately trickle down to consumers at an estimated cost of 45 cents a month, or a combined $436 million annually for cable and satellite subscribers, the agency said.

The government’s case will be led by Craig Conrath, a plain-spoken and longtime litigator who has worked on merger cases for several administrations. He is expected to argue that if the merger is approved, AT&T and Comcast, a corporation that owns distribution and programming — the same combination that AT&T is seeking — would have the incentive to raise prices for access to their shows. That would hurt other cable companies and online streaming businesses.

Judge Leon oversaw the final approval of Comcast’s merger with NBC Universal in 2011, the deal that added programming to Comcast’s holdings.

“Either important video content will be available through a competitive market to all distributors, including up-and-coming innovators,” the Justice Department said in pretrial filings with the court. “Or it will likely only be available through vertically integrated, well-funded silos.”

AT&T scoffs at the government’s predictions of price increases. And even if the analysis is accurate, the company has said, it would amount to the price of a fancy cup of coffee for each consumer. Contrary to the government’s theory that it would withhold content, AT&T says it wants to make sure its shows and movies are as widely distributed as possible.

Leading AT&T’s defense is Daniel Petrocelli, a Los Angeles-based lawyer with a long track record in high-profile cases but not someone who is considered an antitrust expert. Two decades ago, he won a wrongful death case against O. J. Simpson on behalf of the family of Ron Goldman. In 2006, he   lost a case defending Jeffrey Skilling, the chief executive of Enron, of fraud and conspiracy.

Mr. Petrocelli is expected to argue that the government is missing the bigger picture. AT&T says that Silicon Valley companies like Netflix, Amazon, and Google have disrupted the entertainment industry by spending billions of dollars a year on original content and pushing the programming through their own distribution systems. Facebook and Google dominate the market for advertisements that run with those videos.

AT&T argues that a merger with Time Warner would add a new competitor against those giants, instead of reducing competition. AT&T will also promise to work out any contract disputes with cable and satellite companies through a third-party arbitrator, he is expected to argue.

“The new video revolution is defined by the spectacular rise of Netflix, Amazon, Google and other vertically integrated, direct-to-consumer technology companies,” AT&T said in its pretrial brief.

The merger is opposed by several Democratic lawmakers and many consumer groups, who say that AT&T’s control of more than 100 million mobile phone subscriptions gives it unparalleled power. Google, Facebook and Netflix, though mighty, don’t own the pipes that connect people to the internet, they say.

Streaming competition is the “best hope consumers have, but network operators will kill that competition if they are not stopped,” said Mark Cooper, the director of research at the Consumer Federation of America.

Many Wall Street analysts, however, say the government’s intervention in the deal will eventually harm consumers, because it will limit true competitors to the big tech companies.

“The government is about three years behind reality and is defining the marketplace as it was about three years ago,” said Laura Martin, an analyst at Needham & Company.

AT&T had asked for detailed communications logs between the White House and Justice Department staff members, including Mr. Delrahim, a former Trump White House lawyer. Judge Leon rejected those demands, and AT&T ultimately decided to exclude its concerns of potential presidential interference — which it described as “selective enforcement” — from the case.

But even without arguments of political interference entering the trial, many on Wall Street will be looking for clues about the kinds of corporate deals that will pass muster during the Trump administration.

The decision to block a merger between companies that don’t directly compete is rare. Mr. Delrahim has said that one of the common regulatory remedies to prevent anticompetitive behavior in such deals — getting companies to promise they’ll be on their best behavior — is not effective.

That view may ripple across merger and acquisition plans in other sectors, including the drugstore chain CVS’s $69 billion bid for the health insurance provider Aetna — as well as proposed media deals like Disney’s acquisition of Fox and Sinclair Broadcasting’s purchase of Tribune Media. Wall Street analysts expect the results of the trial will determine if more telecom and entertainment companies will pursue ambitious vertical mergers.

“This could direct the future path of the industry,” said Steven Salop, a professor of economics and law at Georgetown University Law School. “If it is permitted, vertical integration will continue.”
