urn:contentItem:60VX-1J71-F03R-N09Y-00000-00Study: One-Third of Americans Want More Regs on Big Tech2020-09-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:19ZLexisNexisStudy: One-Third of Americans Want More Regs on Big TechKayla Sargent

Sep 17, 2020( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/ Delivered by Newstex) It's no secret that Americans have a complicated relationship with Big Tech, and a recent study[1] from FleishmanHillard highlights just how complicated this relationship can be.FleishmanHillard, a St. Louis-based marketing agency and public relations firm, found that 'consumers want the technology sector to take a long hard look at its policies and practices.'According to the study, one-third of Americans want more regulations on Big Tech. Meanwhile, 59 percent believe that the industry is 'Regulated about the right amount.'Although most Americans do not believe that the tech industry needs more regulations, most people believe that companies need to address the consequences of their policies.The study found that 56 percent of Americans at least somewhat agreed with the statement: 'In order to (re)build trust as good corporate citizens who do what's right for consumers, technology companies need to take more action to address the consequences of their policies, practices and products.'

Thirty-one percent of American participants neither agreed nor disagreed with the statement, while only 13 percent disagreed.Although most Americans do believe that Big Tech companies need to 'take more action,' respondents did, overall, express a fair amount of trust in the same companies. 67 percent of participants said that they at least somewhat trust Big Tech companies.Those who do want more regulations for Big Tech may get their wish soon. Sens. Roger Wicker (R-MS), Marsha Blackburn (R-TN) and Lindsey Graham (R-SC) recently introduced legislation[2] to reform Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. The Federal Trade Commission is preparing a possible antitrust lawsuit[3] against Facebook, and Google testified[4] before the Senate in an antitrust hearing on September 15.Conservatives are under attack. Contact the FCC at 1-888-225-5322 and submit a comment[5] on the petition filed by the Department of Commerce regarding Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act of 1996. Demand that Big Tech be held to account to mirror the First Amendment while providing transparency, clarity on 'hate speech' and equal footing for conservatives. If you have been censored, contact us at the Media Research Center contact form[6], and help us hold Big Tech accountable. It’s no secret that Americans have a complicated relationship with Big Tech, and a recent study from FleishmanHillard highlights just how complicated this relationship can be. FleishmanHillard, a St. Louis-based marketing agency and public relations firm, ...

It’s no secret that Americans have a complicated relationship with Big Tech, and a recent study from FleishmanHillard highlights just how complicated this relationship can be. FleishmanHillard, a St. Louis-based marketing agency and public relations firm, found that “consumers want the technology sector to take a long hard look at its policies and practices.” According to the study, one-third of Americans want more regulations on Big Tech. Meanwhile, 59 percent believe that the industry is “Regulated about the right amount.” Although most Americans do not believe that the tech industry needs more regulations, most people believe that companies need to address the consequences of their policies. The study found that 56 percent of Americans at least somewhat agreed with the statement: “In order to (re)build trust as good corporate citizens who do what’s right for consumers, technology companies need to take more action to address the consequences of their policies, practices and products.” Thirty-one percent of American participants neither agreed nor disagreed with the statement, while only 13 percent disagreed. Although most Americans do believe that Big Tech companies need to “take more action,” respondents did, overall, express a fair amount of trust in the same companies. 67 percent of participants said that they at least somewhat trust Big Tech companies. Those who do want more regulations for Big Tech may get their wish soon. Sens. Roger Wicker (R-MS), Marsha Blackburn (R-TN) and Lindsey Graham (R-SC) recently introduced legislation to reform Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. The Federal Trade Commission is preparing a possible antitrust lawsuit against Facebook, and Google testified before the Senate in an antitrust hearing on September 15. Conservatives are under attack. Contact the FCC at 1-888-225-5322 and submit a comment on the petition filed by the Department of Commerce regarding Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act of 1996. Demand that Big Tech be held to account to mirror the First Amendment while providing transparency, clarity on “hate speech” and equal footing for conservatives. If you have been censored, contact us at the Media Research Center contact form , and help us hold Big Tech accountable.

urn:contentItem:5S2R-VM81-F17J-S1JB-00000-00Study to analyse OTT companies in Indonesia2017-11-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:19ZLexisNexisStudy to analyse OTT companies in IndonesiaNews Desk

Think tank Centre for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) is conducting a study on the social and economic impacts over-the-top (OTT) companies will bring to Indonesia amid the government’s move to regulate their playing field.

Scheduled to be completed by next February, the in-depth study is commissioned by the Asia Internet Coalition (AIC), which represents the world’s leading technology companies in Asia, to help regulators implement well-informed policies in the future.

In an effort to gain insight and help guide its research, the group held a closed-door meeting in Jakarta on Tuesday with representatives from the Communications and Information Ministry, major OTT players, such as Apple, Facebook and Netflix, and other relevant stakeholders.

“We were trying to understand the proposed OTT regulation that the government is currently drafting. There were a bunch of provisions in it,” CSIS economic researcher Grace Dewi told The Jakarta Post.

In the meeting, the stakeholders reached a consensus that the digital economy was an integral part of the economy and should be supported as its value was expected to reach US$130 billion by 2020.

However, despite its rising popularity, the e-commerce industry was in the early stages of development, AIC managing director Jeff Paine said.

“I think that the challenge is that the industry is still very nascent; you just don’t want to do anything that will disrupt the growth engine that the e-commerce is on,” he said.

The AIC claims that the government’s plan to issue a ministerial decree to regulate OTT companies by the end of the year will impede the growth of the digital industry because of unclear provisions, including the basic scope and definition of OTT firms.

“The draft regulation as it is written now contains a lot of ambiguities. The definition of OTT covers basically everything on the internet,” Paine said.

Even so, some industry players were concerned with the government’s requirement of OTT players to have a permanent establishment (BUT) in Indonesia, something they saw as burdensome because of their existing presence in more than 200 countries, he said.

The government has taken firm measures toward OTT content providers that do not comply with the country’s regulations, holding them accountable to their tax obligations and ability to provide improved data protection and customer services.

Communications and Information Minister Rudiantara reiterated several times that it was important to level the playing field between local and foreign content providers in regard to their tax obligations.

Beyond Indonesia, tax authorities in many other countries and jurisdictions constantly seek new measures to tax the online giants. The European Union, for instance, has pushed ahead with its strategies and tax rules to force big tech firms, such as Amazon, Facebook and Google, to meet their tax obligations.

A report made by EU lawmakers responsible for a corporate tax reform recently revealed that its member states lost 5.4 billion euros in tax revenues from Google and Facebook between 2013 and 2015, as quoted by Reuters.

Apart from taxation issues, the Indonesian government required Facebook Inc. messaging service WhatsApp to remove obscene content in the form of GIF images after Rudiantara threatened to block its service in the country.

Rudiantara has also threatened to block services from the world’s biggest social media providers, namely Google and Twitter, if they do not adhere to the government’s request to block pornographic content.

He made the move based on Indonesia’s bargaining position, which he perceived as strong given the country’s population of 260 million, a huge market that might be impossible for tech giants to ignore.

Source: The Jakarta Post (Indonesia)

urn:contentItem:5WT6-6291-F03R-N38V-00000-00Study: Trump's paid Peter Thiel's Palantir $1.5B so far to build ICE's mass-surveillance network2019-08-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:19ZLexisNexisStudy: Trump's paid Peter Thiel's Palantir $1.5B so far to build ICE's mass-surveillance networkTristan Greene

Aug 12, 2019( TheNextWeb.com: http://thenextweb.com Delivered by Newstex) Credit: Getty, Drew Angerer Perhaps no other company has profited more from the Trump administration's treatment of undocumented immigrants — and US citizens[1] of similar appearance — than Peter Thiel's Palantir. A recent investigation[2], conducted by Mijente, revealed the US government has at least 29 active contracts with the company worth approximately $1.5 billion. This covers Palantir's work with all four branches of the military, Border Patrol, ICE, and Homeland Security, but it doesn't even touch on the hundreds of contracts it has with local law enforcement throughout the country.

All in all the company's valued at over $20 billion[3]. Peter Thiel, the tech billionaire responsible for PayPal, current Facebook board member, and the co-founder of Palantir, is a vocal Conservative and prominent Trump supporter. He was the President's seventh largest[4] campaign donor in 2016 and remains a staunch ally. But it wasn't President Trump who brought Palantir into the country's fold, that distinguishment belongs to President Barrack Obama.Trump's simply elevated the company to the kind of status that's traditionally been reserved for big players such as Raytheon and Boeing. The result's been a match made in Conservative heaven. Using AI designed for the military, Palantir's managed to take wartime technology and implement it at scale across the entire US police industrial complex, causing a complete shift in how law enforcement treats citizen privacy. This concept was described perfectly by Pacific Standard's Jacqui Shine in a 2017 article[5]: Commentators who refer to a 'police-industrial complex' are usually describing the militarization of police agencies: the steady adoption, which escalated after September 11, 2001, of military technologies and strategies for domestic law enforcement purposes. But in market terms, there is also a distinct police-industrial complex, in which public-private relationships between law enforcement agencies and a wide variety of for-profit corporations have come to shape our society's very conceptions of policing and our priorities for justice. Today, Donald Trump's party-line nationalism is what directs the US surveillance state. But surveillance isn't a Republican or Democrat technology: it's an anti-freedom one. It's a Pandora's Box that will remain long after the current controlling party is gone, and we have big tech to thank. According to the Mijente report:We could not 20 years ago have envisioned a world in which immigration agents could scour national databases to build sophisticated profiles of us and pinpoint our locations for arrest, or in which border patrol agents could man all-seeing surveillance towers to fully monitor the frontier with Mexico, immediately spotting anyone walking in the desert. If we are not careful, we will not know what we will be fighting in 20 years. We must understand, document, and oppose these dangerous partnerships today.Trump andThiel have created a profit-machine based on disguising mass-surveillance as 'data analytics.' These tools can't predict crime or terrorism[6], as they're purported to by Palantir. And they certainly can't use algorithms to magically predict where an undocumented immigrant is likely to be — they're not mere administrative tools designed to help manage investigations for overwhelmed agents, they're illegal, unconstitutional surveillance portals[7]. In order to understand just how much information Palantir has on you, here's a list of just some of the public and private databases that Palantir has access to per a Vicereport[8]:On top of this, Palantir has access to classified military data, facial recognition cameras across the country and at the borders, and the complete trust and cooperation of the Federal government and hundreds of local law enforcement agencies. It's a surveillance machine[9] capable of tracking anyone and everyone. And the company's now deeply embedded within the US government. Its contracts will outlast Trump's presidency even if he serves a second term. Those who currently sit silently - or cheer[10] - as the government uses mass surveillance and dragnet policing to round up and incarcerate undocumented immigrants should consider how easy it'll be to turn this technology on citizens. urn:contentItem:5SY0-TGV1-JBG3-610F-00000-00Stumbles? What Stumbles? Big Tech Is as Strong as Ever;State of the Art2018-08-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:19ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYStumbles? What Stumbles? Big Tech Is as Strong as EverState of the ArtFarhad Manjoo

Facebook’s earnings report sent tech stocks cratering. But don’t let that fool you: Apple, Google, Facebook, Amazon and Microsoft are still on their way to dominating the future.

You may have heard that the tech giants are on their heels.

Over the last two years, lawmakers and the public around the globe have been awakened to fears about the expanding powers of the largest technology companies, particularly the ones I’ve called the Frightful Five: Apple, Amazon, Google, Facebook and Microsoft, the most valuable companies on the American markets.

The concerns span the gamut. There are calls for renewed antitrust investigations. Some people have accused the companies of political biases, while others have criticized their lack of diversity and how narrowly they distribute their wealth. Then there are the questions of their vulnerability to foreign influence and their capacity for addicting us to their products.

In different ways, the companies have conceded some of these fears and have vowed to address them. Taking stock, cleaning up, admitting “moral responsibility” for their contributions to society — these are the buzzwords of a tech ecosystem that is supposedly subsumed by remorse and committed to rehabilitation.

Yet there is something deeply incongruous at the heart of the supposed “techlash”: It is not really making a huge dent in the tech giants’ financial performance. Over the last two weeks, each of the five reported earnings that were brimming with mostly fantastic news for its investors. Amazon, which has long conditioned shareholders to expect a lot of growth but not much earnings, reported a record profit. Microsoft and Google’s parent company, Alphabet, both handily beat Wall Street’s projections. On Tuesday,   so did Apple; if its price jumps as a result, it could become the first company to reach a market valuation of more than $1 trillion.

Wait, but what about Facebook, which told investors to expect lower growth rates and higher expenses, causing its stock to lose $120 billion in market value in a single day?

In a strange way, the social network’s troubles only underscored its dominance. Even after its stock crash, Facebook remains the fifth most valuable corporation in the American markets, ahead of Berkshire Hathaway, and there are almost no serious calls for its chief executive to resign, as you might expect for any other company experiencing such a loss. That’s because the company reported little to cause experts to alter their long-term outlook. Pretty much everyone who studies Facebook believes that it will hold its grip on the culture and the advertising industry for the foreseeable future.

“This is one of the most profitable business models I’ve ever seen, and that really hasn’t changed,” said Mark Mahaney, an analyst at the firm RBC Capital. He added that Facebook’s stock now “may be the single most attractively priced asset across technology.”

Together the earning statements tell a clear story. Despite the public outcry, the five are all expanding their foothold in our lives, and the forces arrayed against them, which range from regulation to apathy, aren’t having a substantial impact. To the extent that the five companies face meaningful competition, it is usually from other members of the group; that is, one of the five might steal market share from another without affecting the overall dynamic in the tech business.

Why is this happening? If you dig into their reports, you find several powerful forces keeping these companies at the top.

Software really is eating the world

Back when it was just an e-commerce company, Amazon was dogged by a persistent worry: Could it ever make a lot of money? The company has spent more than two decades methodically building out its capacity to deliver an ever larger number of products at an ever-increasing rate. That takes a lot of investment, so even though Amazon’s sales grew like crazy every year, it had to plow its revenue back into further expansion.

Three years ago, Amazon began to report small but consistent profits. And in the last year, its earnings began to grow, and now they’ve reached a level that stands out even in the tech industry. In the quarter ending in June, Amazon booked a $2.5 billion profit. That’s only about half what Facebook made, but it is real money.

Where did Amazon find all the new money? The same place the tech industry always finds profits: software. Though most people think of Amazon as a place to buy toilet paper, the vast majority of its profits come from its cloud-services business, Amazon Web Services, which allows companies to store their data on Amazon’s servers rather than locally. Another new source of profits is its advertising business, which charges companies to place ads for their products across Amazon’s site.

For rival retailers, Amazon’s new profitability constitutes a kind of nightmare scenario. By shuttling profits from software into its retail business, Amazon can keep expanding its store at a breakneck pace.

“These high-margin businesses allow Amazon to run its entire store at close to zero margin — and once you do that, it becomes effectively impossible for someone whose sole business is commerce to compete with you,” said Youssef Squali, an analyst at the firm SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.

But it’s not just Amazon that’s profiting under the venture capitalist Marc Andreessen’s thesis that “software is eating the world.” Microsoft’s surging earnings were   also driven by its cloud business, while Apple’s software services — things like sales of apps, music subscriptions, cloud storage and Apple Pay — are   the fastest-growing part of its business.

Regulatory pressure isn’t having a huge impact

The European Union recently fined Google $5.1 billion for abusing its mobile software monopoly, which followed   a $2.7 billion fine last year for abuse of its search monopoly. (Google is appealing both decisions.) Apple agreed last year to pay nearly $16 billion in back taxes to the European Union over its cozy tax deal with Ireland. (The funds will be held in escrow while Ireland appeals the decision; Apple has disputed any wrongdoing.) Facebook, which has been hauled before lawmakers in Europe and the United States for its role in politics, faces threats of increased regulation and possible fines for mishandling private data.

But Big Tech’s earnings so far don’t show much of an impact from the increased scrutiny. Google paid its fine and still reported a $3.2 billion quarterly profit. Neither Google nor Facebook saw much of an effect from Europe’s new privacy rule, the General Data Protection Regulation. Facebook’s user base declined by only a million users in Europe (367 million people use it every month there). Both companies warned that the law may have a greater effect in the future, but several analysts said both Google and Facebook could benefit from the law, because compliance costs could sink their smaller rivals.

There is also the possibility that regulatory zeal will abate. Google watchers say it’s notable that President Trump tweeted criticism of the European Union’s fine against Google, suggesting, perhaps, that American regulators won’t take up a similar case. (Of course, it is hard these days to really know how much to read into a presidential tweet.)

Or consider the changing dynamics of the digital advertising business, which is dominated by Google and Facebook and has been a top target of antitrust activists. Amazon’s growing ad business poses a threat to both Google and Facebook — which suggests that the ad economy is becoming more competitive even without the government’s help.

“There’s been this fear that advertising was going to become a duopoly owned by Google and Facebook,” Mr. Mahaney said. “Now it’s going to be a triopoly — but if you were worried about the duopoly, you’re probably saying, ‘Couldn’t the third company have been someone besides Amazon?’”

The Five still have a lot more ways to make money

Finally, there are what Mr. Mahaney calls the “green fields” — the nearly endless opportunities that many of the Five have to start minting more and more money from various parts of their businesses.

Facebook, for instance, has experienced a slowdown in the growth of its core social network, but its other properties — Instagram, Facebook Messenger and WhatsApp among them — are still growing quickly, and the company has only just started to make money from them. At Google, there’s a similar opportunity for YouTube, which, like Facebook, will benefit from the billions in TV advertising money that marketers will shift online over the next few years.

And that’s just in the short term. The earnings reports show that all of the five are investing heavily in the tech that will dominate the future, from artificial intelligence to voice services to self-driving cars.

“The one thing that is likely to keep these companies at the top for much longer than traditional megacap companies is that they are not afraid to reinvent themselves,” Mr. Squali said. “They see themselves as laboratories for new ideas, and they’re not afraid to destroy something that’s working today to make the longer-term work even better for them.”

In other words: Get used to the Five. They’re not going anywhere.

urn:contentItem:5SXT-YSD1-DYR7-C1WM-00000-00Stumbles? What Stumbles? Big Tech Is as Strong as Ever;State of the Art2018-08-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:19ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYStumbles? What Stumbles? Big Tech Is as Strong as EverState of the ArtFARHAD MANJOOABSTRACT

Facebook's earnings report sent tech stocks cratering. But don't let that fool you: Apple, Google, Facebook, Amazon and Microsoft are still on their way to dominating the future.

FULL TEXT

You may have heard that the tech giants are on their heels.

Over the last two years, lawmakers and the public around the globe have been awakened to fears about the expanding powers of the largest technology companies, particularly the ones I've called the Frightful Five: Apple, Amazon, Google, Facebook and Microsoft, the most valuable companies on the American markets.

The concerns span the gamut. There are calls for renewed antitrust investigations. Some people have accused the companies of political biases, while others have criticized their lack of diversity and how narrowly they distribute their wealth. Then there are the questions of their vulnerability to foreign influence and their capacity for addicting us to their products.

In different ways, the companies have conceded some of these fears and have vowed to address them. Taking stock, cleaning up, admitting "moral responsibility" for their contributions to society - these are the buzzwords of a tech ecosystem that is supposedly subsumed by remorse and committed to rehabilitation.

Yet there is something deeply incongruous at the heart of the supposed "techlash": It is not really making a huge dent in the tech giants' financial performance. Over the last two weeks, each of the five reported earnings that were brimming with mostly fantastic news for its investors. Amazon, which has long conditioned shareholders to expect a lot of growth but not much earnings, reported a record profit. Microsoft and Google's parent company, Alphabet, both handily beat Wall Street's projections. On Tuesday, so did Apple; if its price jumps as a result, it could become the first company to reach a market valuation of more than $1 trillion.

Wait, but what about Facebook, which told investors to expect lower growth rates and higher expenses, causing its stock to lose $120 billion in market value in a single day?

In a strange way, the social network's troubles only underscored its dominance. Even after its stock crash, Facebook remains the fifth most valuable corporation in the American markets, ahead of Berkshire Hathaway, and there are almost no serious calls for its chief executive to resign, as you might expect for any other company experiencing such a loss. That's because the company reported little to cause experts to alter their long-term outlook. Pretty much everyone who studies Facebook believes that it will hold its grip on the culture and the advertising industry for the foreseeable future.

"This is one of the most profitable business models I've ever seen, and that really hasn't changed," said Mark Mahaney, an analyst at the firm RBC Capital. He added that Facebook's stock now "may be the single most attractively priced asset across technology."

Together the earning statements tell a clear story. Despite the public outcry, the five are all expanding their foothold in our lives, and the forces arrayed against them, which range from regulation to apathy, aren't having a substantial impact. To the extent that the five companies face meaningful competition, it is usually from other members of the group; that is, one of the five might steal market share from another without affecting the overall dynamic in the tech business.

Why is this happening? If you dig into their reports, you find several powerful forces keeping these companies at the top.

Software really is eating the world

Back when it was just an e-commerce company, Amazon was dogged by a persistent worry: Could it ever make a lot of money? The company has spent more than two decades methodically building out its capacity to deliver an ever larger number of products at an ever-increasing rate. That takes a lot of investment, so even though Amazon's sales grew like crazy every year, it had to plow its revenue back into further expansion.

Three years ago, Amazon began to report small but consistent profits. And in the last year, its earnings began to grow, and now they've reached a level that stands out even in the tech industry. In the quarter ending in June, Amazon booked a $2.5 billion profit. That's only about half what Facebook made, but it is real money.

Where did Amazon find all the new money? The same place the tech industry always finds profits: software. Though most people think of Amazon as a place to buy toilet paper, the vast majority of its profits come from its cloud-services business, Amazon Web Services, which allows companies to store their data on Amazon's servers rather than locally. Another new source of profits is its advertising business, which charges companies to place ads for their products across Amazon's site.

For rival retailers, Amazon's new profitability constitutes a kind of nightmare scenario. By shuttling profits from software into its retail business, Amazon can keep expanding its store at a breakneck pace.

"These high-margin businesses allow Amazon to run its entire store at close to zero margin - and once you do that, it becomes effectively impossible for someone whose sole business is commerce to compete with you," said Youssef Squali, an analyst at the firm SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.

But it's not just Amazon that's profiting under the venture capitalist Marc Andreessen's thesis that "software is eating the world." Microsoft's surging earnings were also driven by its cloud business, while Apple's software services - things like sales of apps, music subscriptions, cloud storage and Apple Pay - are the fastest-growing part of its business.

Regulatory pressure isn't having a huge impact

The European Union recently fined Google $5.1 billion for abusing its mobile software monopoly, which followed a $2.7 billion fine last year for abuse of its search monopoly. (Google is appealing both decisions.) Apple agreed last year to pay nearly $16 billion in back taxes to the European Union over its cozy tax deal with Ireland. (The funds will be held in escrow while Ireland appeals the decision; Apple has disputed any wrongdoing.) Facebook, which has been hauled before lawmakers in Europe and the United States for its role in politics, faces threats of increased regulation and possible fines for mishandling private data.

But Big Tech's earnings so far don't show much of an impact from the increased scrutiny. Google paid its fine and still reported a $3.2 billion quarterly profit. Neither Google nor Facebook saw much of an effect from Europe's new privacy rule, the General Data Protection Regulation. Facebook's user base declined by only a million users in Europe (367 million people use it every month there). Both companies warned that the law may have a greater effect in the future, but several analysts said both Google and Facebook could benefit from the law, because compliance costs could sink their smaller rivals.

There is also the possibility that regulatory zeal will abate. Google watchers say it's notable that President Trump tweeted criticism of the European Union's fine against Google, suggesting, perhaps, that American regulators won't take up a similar case. (Of course, it is hard these days to really know how much to read into a presidential tweet.)

Or consider the changing dynamics of the digital advertising business, which is dominated by Google and Facebook and has been a top target of antitrust activists. Amazon's growing ad business poses a threat to both Google and Facebook - which suggests that the ad economy is becoming more competitive even without the government's help.

"There's been this fear that advertising was going to become a duopoly owned by Google and Facebook," Mr. Mahaney said. "Now it's going to be a triopoly - but if you were worried about the duopoly, you're probably saying, 'Couldn't the third company have been someone besides Amazon?'"

The Five still have a lot more ways to make money

Finally, there are what Mr. Mahaney calls the "green fields" - the nearly endless opportunities that many of the Five have to start minting more and more money from various parts of their businesses.

Facebook, for instance, has experienced a slowdown in the growth of its core social network, but its other properties - Instagram, Facebook Messenger and WhatsApp among them - are still growing quickly, and the company has only just started to make money from them. At Google, there's a similar opportunity for YouTube, which, like Facebook, will benefit from the billions in TV advertising money that marketers will shift online over the next few years.

And that's just in the short term. The earnings reports show that all of the five are investing heavily in the tech that will dominate the future, from artificial intelligence to voice services to self-driving cars.

"The one thing that is likely to keep these companies at the top for much longer than traditional megacap companies is that they are not afraid to reinvent themselves," Mr. Squali said. "They see themselves as laboratories for new ideas, and they're not afraid to destroy something that's working today to make the longer-term work even better for them."

In other words: Get used to the Five. They're not going anywhere.

urn:contentItem:5RKH-CWH1-DXH2-609F-00000-00Stunning news about Russia investigations; Report: Schiff took calls with Russian pranksters about dirty Trump pics; Is the government spying on Americans?; Democrats and FBI abuses; Colts linebacker killed in crash by illegal immigrant; Hillary Clinton blames sexism, among other things, for loss; Google patents reveal the future of tech; PepsiCo considers snacks for women; Canadian PM tells woman to say "peoplekind"2018-02-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:19ZLexisNexisTUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT8:00 PM ESTMark Pocan, Sharyl Attkisson, David Garrow, Pramila Jayapal, Tristan Harris, Jim Steyer, Cathy AreuNEWSDomestic020601cb.260Stunning news about Russia investigations; Report: Schiff took calls with Russian pranksters about dirty Trump pics; Is the government spying on Americans?; Democrats and FBI abuses; Colts linebacker killed in crash by illegal immigrant; Hillary Clinton blames sexism, among other things, for loss; Google patents reveal the future of tech; PepsiCo considers snacks for women; Canadian PM tells woman to say "peoplekind"Tucker Carlson

TUCKER CARLSON, FOX NEWS HOST, TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT: Good evening and welcome to TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT.

We've got some stunning news for you about the ongoing Russia investigation. News that will challenge everything you thought you knew about the story. Yesterday, we showed you the terrifying extent to which Vladimir Putin's sinister tendrils have encircled the American body politic, crushing the very life from this republic.

Russian agents are so intent on undermining our democracy, they've taken to promoting our own Bill of Rights back to us. The Second Amendment specifically.

Now, we'll admit, we are not exactly sure how that's bad. But Adam Schiff has assured us that it is. And because Schiff is a prominent member of Congress and often appears on cable news, we believe him.

Now, tonight, we've learned that the foreign subversion goes even deeper than that. The Russian conspiracy is so subtle, so crafty, such a bewildering Slavic hall of mirrors that the people warning us about Russia are, in fact, key players in the Russian conspiracy. The leaders of the witch-hunt are witches.

Sound impossible? Listen to this. Last year, the director of national intelligence released the definitive report on Russia propaganda efforts in this country. The main focus of that report was the Russian cable channel "RT America", which is funded and controlled by the Putin government.

In the words of our intelligence community, RT engages in "anti-US messaging likely aimed at undermining viewers trust in US democratic procedures."

Our government considers "RT" so dangerous that the channel has been forced to register as a foreign agent. "RT" employees who fail to register could face prison time. No outlet in this country has ever been forced to do that. "RT" is a sinister place. Everybody says so.

So, who would go on a channel like that, one whose sole agenda is to discredit and destroy the American experiment? Well, none other than Adam Bennett Schiff of Burbank, California. You know him as Congressman Adam Schiff, the ranking Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee, the man leading the charge against Vladimir Putin's propaganda machine.

And yet, Adam Schiff was part of that machine. Seriously. Here's an actual screenshot. Just so you know, we're not making this up. Though his office refused to confirm it tonight, we can assure you that that is indeed Adam Schiff, the one and only.

In our appearance that our producers reviewed - Adam Schiff's appearance, Schiff seemed to promote conspiracy theories about the US government, suggesting that the men and women who lay down their live to keep us safe may be twisting information for their own purposes.

Here's a quote. "We only see what the intelligence community wants us to see." Adam Schiff said that on "Russian Television". There must've been applause in the Kremlin when he did.

But Schiff isn't alone. Congressman Jim Hines of Connecticut also appeared on Vladimir Putin's cable channel. In one appearance, Himes said this about our men in uniform and their civilian leaders. "The invasion of Iraq, I would argue, the great American foreign policy mistake of the century." Well, in the background, you could almost hear Vladimir Putin cackling with glee.

So, here you have two prominent members of Congress voluntarily appearing on a foreign propaganda outlet in order to undermine confidence in America's core institutions. As they might put it, doing the bidding of a hostile foreign power.

Tokyo Rose went to prison for that. Now, we are not suggesting prison at this point. That's a decision a new special counsel and federal grand juries will have to make after an appropriately extensive and independent investigation into all of this. That could take years. Not that justice has a timetable.

In the meantime, Schiff and Hines must recuse themselves immediately from any role in the Russia investigation, including appearances on "MSNBC's" primetime lineup.

We assume the special counsel will also take up the mysterious and troubling case of the non-existent nude photographs, a story just broken by "The Daily Mail" hours ago.

Last year, Adam Schiff conducted a phone call with Russian pranksters, who promised him compromising photographs of Donald Trump with a Russian model. Schiff's office claims the congressman wasn't fooled by the prank. The call's transcript suggests otherwise.

Schiff continued that conversation for more than 8 minutes and appeared to be taking notes during it. After the call, Schiff's office contacted somebody they believed was Ukrainian politician, seeking to set up a meeting at a foreign embassy where they could obtain those documents.

Huh! Let's see. Setting up meetings with foreign operatives seeking politically damaging information about a political opponent? We thought that was treason. Adam Schiff told us it was.

Congressman Mark Pocan is a colleague of Mr. Schiff's. He's a Democrat representing the State of Wisconsin and he joins us tonight. Mr. Pocan, thanks for coming on.

REP. MARK POCAN (D), WISCONSIN: Glad to be here, Tucker.

CARLSON: So, the intelligence community - our intelligence community described "RT" as a key component of the Russian propaganda machine. And here you have one of the leaders, one of the grand inquisitors in the Russia investigation appearing on it, willfully being used by the Russian government to propagandize our people, to undermine our democracy, to hack our way of life.

Why should he not recuse himself immediately from the investigation on the basis of that?

POCAN: I assume from the whole intro you were doing that as tongue-in- cheek because, clearly, as you know, politicians are on many, many networks. And I don't think he was, as you are trying to describe, saying that "RT" is trying to undermine American democracy in doing something.

I got the point - I get the point. I think we all get the point.

CARLSON: I'm just using the standards that everyone in Washington is using at "The Washington Post" and leaders of your party are using.

If you have contact with the Russian government, and particularly if you willingly participate in Russian propaganda efforts -

POCAN: Tucker, you don't honestly believe that someone being on a network doing an appearance - and for all you know, it could've been on sugar content and food.

CARLSON: No, it was on American intelligence gathering. I watched it today. So, he's going on Vladimir Putin's propaganda, what to talk about, American intelligence gathering. Does that bother you?

POCAN: Tucker, you're comparing that to what we know ultimately happened. There were people who set up meetings in the Trump family with Russians in order to get information and you are trying to compare that to "RT". I just don't know if it was very effective.

CARLSON: We know for a fact that Adam Schiff did exactly that last year.

POCAN: Are you honestly - if I go on Fox Network, therefore I'm tainted by Fox Network forever?

CARLSON: And by the way - look -

POCAN: That wouldn't make a lot of sense, Tucker.

CARLSON: My only point is this is total McCarthyite witch-hunt, as you know. And the attorney general recused himself because he shook the hand of the Russian ambassador. The whole thing is a joke.

But we might as well, if we are going to use these standards, keep to them.

POCAN: Tucker, what I will agree about a joke is, I think, this memo that Devin Nunes, after being forced to recuse himself from the investigation after doing, like, small town community theater, where remember the one night he got out of the car and went to the White House to get info. The next day, "I've got info" and he gave it to the White House?

The fact that he then directed this memo, which now we all know there is nothing in that, I think that is far more substantive than you're making a tongue-in-cheek point about that one.

CARLSON: I'm not here to defend Devin Nunes. I do think it raises important questions for all American citizens about what the criteria are, the government choosing to spy on Americans. And they are clearly quite low. And that bothers me.

POCAN: Tucker, where we might find some agreement is, I along with many Republicans and Democrats had problems when we reauthorized FISA because we want to keep it tighter, right?

CARLSON: Nobody should have voted for it.

POCAN: I just think some of the people now who are trying to use the memo should have also been around there if they knew it at that time, why did they allow the reauthorization of FISA to happen.

So, again, it just shows again one more reason why that memo is such a joke.

CARLSON: I'm with you on that. It doesn't necessarily discredit the memo, but it's a real question.

I'm going to ask you about an actual story just broken in "The Daily Mail" that shows that Adam Schiff had a phone call with two comedians who he believed were Russian and they offered him photographs of Donald Trump with a Russian model.

He says he thought - he knew it was a prank. That's clearly a lie because he dispatched a member of his committee staff, Rheanne Wirkkala - makes 100 grand a year; we checked, she works there - and she emailed them and said this. "I understand Mr. Schiff had a productive meeting. Would you like to make some material available to Mr. Schiff through your embassy?".

Then, again, she said, "Let me know the best way to pick up these materials from your embassy in Washington." And she emailed back the next day. "Do you know when we might be able to meet your colleagues at the Ukrainian embassy here in Washington to pick up the materials?"

How is that not Adam Schiff's' office coordinating with foreign agents to get damaging material on a political opponent? Isn't that exactly what Trump is being accused of?

POCAN: Not even close. But I think you should bring Adam in and ask him that.

CARLSON: Well, he's too cowardly to come on the show. He accused me of working for Putin and then would never come on again.

But I just want to ask you, how is that - how is that OK?

POCAN: It's significantly different. So, first of all, this is one of the issues - I got PolitiFacted on - no one likes to be PolitiFacted in case you're wrong. I was PolitiFacted on that meeting that they had at Trump Tower with the Russian individual. And I got I think a mostly true because I said they came in the back door and we couldn't verify that they came in the back door. It could have been a side door and a window.

CARLSON: We've talked about that before.

POCAN: But it's a completely different situation. Are you actually equating the two?

CARLSON: I'm actually simply asking a very straightforward question.

POCAN: Yes, yes. I mean, are you equating the two? Because I don't.

CARLSON: It doesn't even matter how it compares to anything else. On its own terms, is it all right for the ranking member, Democratic member of the intel committee to set up a meeting -

POCAN: I think you need to have him to see, so he can explain if it was - what I believe I saw in your intro was that he said it was a comedian.

CARLSON: No, no. We have the emails from his staff.

POCAN: Then he would be a great guest to try to book on it. But I can't talk about it in an interview that I wasn't -

CARLSON: You can't talk about something someone else did? But you can talk about what Donald Trump Jr. did. He's not here.

POCAN: You are equating it to a meeting that's very well-publicized that we know about now.

CARLSON: We learned about this today.

POCAN: Yes. We learned today and the other one we've known for quite a long -

CARLSON: We have irrefutable evidence he was trying to get information from a foreign government - it's right here! Let's put it on the screen again.

POCAN: If the best we have is "RT" and a Russian comedian, is that really the best?

CARLSON: No! The best we have is a member of the intel committee staff right there, Rheanne Wirkkala -

POCAN: Tucker, I expect better.

CARLSON: I'm actually dead serious.

POCAN: This is kind of like local communicators. Devin Nunes could do this.

CARLSON: No, no. I'm serious.

POCAN: I'm surprised that you are. I have a lot more respect for you.

CARLSON: You are not going to engage, are you?

POCAN: It's kind of ridiculous. It really is.

CARLSON: Oh, it is? It's just a joke?

POCAN: So far, what you're putting up today is - seriously, when you had the intro as I watched it on sitting next to you, I thought it was tongue- in-cheek just to kind of prove a point.

CARLSON: The first part was. The Democratic Party has lost its mind and it is conducting a McCarthyite witch hunt.

POCAN: It is the president who said members of Congress who didn't applaud are committing treason.

CARLSON: I hated that. I hated that. I'm not here to defend Trump. I'm here to defend the basic civil liberties I grew up with.

POCAN: And I think you and I probably have some agreement on the FISA -

CARLSON: Why don't you get on this one and we can talk about it later because it's interesting.

POCAN: I will take a look and I'll read it.

CARLSON: Appreciate it.

Spats over Russia are distracting from the real issue of the Nunes menu, the possibility that intelligence services are spying on you and other American citizens without real restrictions.

Sharyl Attkisson host Sinclair's "Full Measure" has herself said that she's the target of government surveillance and she joins us tonight. Sharyl, thanks a lot for coming on. You spent years on this question with basically no support from your colleagues in the media or relatively little.

Are you surprised by the posture in the press which is, it is wrong to want to know more about who the government is spying on?

ATTKISSON: Well, I'm not because, as I've written in the last couple of years and spoken to, I think the press in general, while there are still many good reporters doing independent reporting, it's getting harder.

We have invited some of the propagandists into our newsrooms, we allow them to dictate the talking points and messages du jour. And it's getting more difficult, I think, to find sort of down the middle, unbiased reporting.

CARLSON: But shouldn't the default position of a journalist be more information rather than less? So, when we learned last week of the possibility that the US government spied on a US citizen on the basis of pretty flaky information, was it weird to see reporters stand up and say, tell us no more! We don't want to know! In fact, you are unpatriotic if you want to know more.

ATTKISSON: I've never seen anything like it. in fact, I commented that I've never, in my lifetime, seen open government groups and journalists so uncurious and begging not to be told about alleged or supposed violations of citizens' rights.

And this leads into a much larger picture, I think, of surveillance abuses that have occurred over the past 10, 20 years involving citizens, politicians and journalists.

CARLSON: So, I mean, just to do the opposite of putting our fears to rest, this is not as uncommon as we hope it is, is it?

ATTKISSON: I think not. Long before Trump announced running for president, I had intel sources, contacts, who I'm still in touch with, who have said that for a long time there has been presentation of bad evidence to the FISA court to justify warrants, that there has been sort of a reverse engineering when political figures want to target people illegally.

They find someone in their orbit that they can target and then capture them incidentally and then accidentally capture their data and unmask them acting surprised that that's who it was when that's the target that they intended to capture all along.

Tucker: It's totally wrong. Sharyl Attkisson, you are one of the first to call attention to this kind of thing and we're grateful for that. Thank you.

ATTKISSON: Thanks.

CARLSON: David Garrow is a historian. He's written excessively on the FBI in a number of different books. In a piece for today's "Wall Street Journal", he says that some members of Congress, including some Democrats, think we are reverting to the J. Edgar Hoover era in the treatment of the FBI. David Garrow joins us tonight.

David, thanks for coming on. We searched -

David Garrow, Author and Historian: Good to talk to you, Tucker.

CARLSON: - for the last three days for the last honest liberal who will stay consistent to liberal values of openness and commitment to civil liberties. Give us some perspective here. When you hear people say the FBI would never do that, you are attacking our guardians by asking that question. Is there some historical precedent for this, would you say?

GARROW: I'm very worried, Tucker, at how people are giving up their principles, their civil liberty principles because of the intensity of their partisan hatred for President Trump.

As you know, I'm a liberal Democrat.

CARLSON: Yes.

GARROW: But what we've got here is Democrats forgetting the history of the FBI and taking up these anti-civil liberty stances defending the FBI simply because of how intensely opposed they are to President Trump.

The FBI does not have a good pedigree on electronic surveillance practices. And everything I'm aware of as a liberal Democrat is that the bureau has been really deceptive with the foreign intelligence court in applying for this extended electronic surveillance of Carter Page, the volunteer Trump advisor.

Liberals and progressives should oppose the FBI's behavior targeting Mr. Page.

CARLSON: Just on civil liberties grounds, having nothing to do with the larger investigation or their like or dislike for Trump, but an American citizen is having his civil liberties violated, liberals should care, right?

GARROW: And based primarily or extensively, it appears, on the dodgy Christopher Steele dossier. I think we both know - again, I'm a liberal Democrat - the Steele dossier is c-r-a-p. It's BS.

The FBI relied upon that in going to federal judges to surveil an American citizen. That's offensive to me as a progressive democrat.

CARLSON: Exactly. David Garrow, author of the definitive biography of the last president Barack Obama. Thanks for joining us tonight.

GARROW: Thank you, Tucker.

CARLSON: An NFL player is dead thanks to the criminal behavior of a twice- deported illegal immigrant. Will it make Congressional Democrats reconsider, and some Republicans, their support for de facto open borders. One of them joins us next. We'll find out. Stay tuned.

CARLSON: NFL player Edwin Jackson of the Indianapolis Colts appears to be the most high-profile recent victim of crime by someone here illegally. Jackson was killed when his ridesharing vehicle was alleged hit by Manuel Orrego-Savala, a twice deported Guatemalan immigrant who was apparently driving drunk without a driver's license.

There was no reason for this man to be in the country, save that our country's politicians are steadfastly determined to let him stay. A recent chart by "Axios" hints at why. Democrats are dominant in districts that have a high immigrant population. Democrats know the math. They know they've alienated middle America, which does not vote for them anymore. And so, immigration is central to their future victories. They cannot win without it.

Congressman Pramila Jayapal is a Democrat representing Seattle, Washington and she joins us tonight. Congresswoman, thanks for coming on.

REP. PRAMILA JAYAPAL (D), WASHINGTON: Happy to be here.

CARLSON: So, you recently said of the Trump immigration proposal that it targets "people of color" and it advances his hate-filled agenda. So, I guess I'm willing to believe that. But the proposal would give amnesty and then citizenship to about 2 million immigrants here illegally, almost all of them people of color. How is that white supremacy?

JAYAPAL: Well, let me just start by saying what he's proposing, which, first of all, Trump is the person who actually made 1.8 million people deportable because until he came along and rescinded DACA, those folks were all here with legal status, working, contributing billions of dollar to our economy.

But then, he said, OK, I'm going to take this group of young people hostage. And, Tucker, across the country, about 90 percent of Americans believe there should be a permanent solution for these young people, for these Dreamers.

And he said, I'm going to hold them hostage. And the ransom is going to be an ever-moving target, but the latest target is we are going to cut legal immigration by 22 million, we are going to have to get rid of the diversity visa. We are going to need to get $25 billion on the border.

So, all of a sudden, 1.8 million immigrants that he made deportable are now being traded for essentially ending legal immigration as we know it.

CARLSON: So, let me just say - by the way, we are getting breaking news that federal immigration charges have just been filed against the driver, apparently drunk in the case that we referenced coming into the segment.

Let me just be clear, though, for most of American history, we have not had a million legal immigrants coming into this country every year. That has not been the rule for our history at all. Not even close to it.

And so, if the cuts you just referred to were to become law, we get back to the 1990s level of legal immigration. Does that suggest that Bill Clinton was a white the supremacist too?

JAYAPAL: No. This really is about - the cornerstone of our country's immigration policy has always been family-based immigration. If you come to this country, you can be here with your kids.

And the Republican Party used to be a party of family values. I don't know that anybody's claiming that today. But the reality is immigration is all about making sure that we continue to have people here who can do the work we need to do, have done - who contribute to the diversity of the country, who contribute their skills.

And across the board, we've had -

CARLSON: That sounds reasonable. Then, why not judge people on those bases? So, the majority of our legal immigrants come because they're related to someone here. We don't look for the most talented people in this or that field, for the majority.

We say, do you have a relative who lives here? You would never hire your congressional staff on that basis. You wouldn't say, oh, I'm going to take your cousin because he's your cousin.

JAYAPAL: That's a faulty premise because you are assuming that they don't bring anything other than being a relative of a family.

CARLSON: No. I'm just saying we don't have - no, no, no. Look, I think it's great when families are unified. I'm very pro-family.

But when you're trying to make the country as impressive as you possibly can, why wouldn't you choose the most impressive possible people -

JAYAPAL: Because we are bringing the most impressive people. If you look at technology companies, the enormous number of people who are immigrants who have started those technology companies, small businesses, same thing.

You look at any field of science, research -

CARLSON: I'm not arguing against immigrants. I'm merely saying, why not get the most impressive ones. You're saying we're required or racists to give citizenship to people who snuck in in here and their parents and their sibling and possibly their grandparents and uncles too or else we're racists. So, that's a hostage situation.

JAYAPAL: But that's just not true. I mean, what you said is not true because we don't allow grandparents into this country. We don't allow cousins to come in and be sponsored. No, we don't. We don't have any categories along that.

If you listen to your show, to people on Fox News, to Donald Trump -

CARLSON: OK, so you're not saying -

JAYAPAL: Hold on, Tucker. Let me just finish my point. If you listen to just what's going on, you would think that this family immigration system is somehow out of control. It's not. It took me 17 years to become a US Citizen.

By the time, I could become a US citizen, my parents were already very elderly and it would've taken another -

CARLSON: So, let me just ask you, does this standard apply to any other country? So, you met with Prime Minister Modi of India. Would you say to him, you need to let every person who sneaks in from Pakistan become a voting citizen immediately or else you're racist.

JAYAPAL: That's just not what we are talking about. We are talking about - no, it's not.

CARLSON: You're saying people who snuck in have to be given citizenship.

JAYAPAL: No, what I'm saying is we need to have an immigration system that actually recognizes the needs of our economy, the needs of our communities.

CARLSON: Is there any other country that should have these standards applied to it.

JAYAPAL: There are lots of countries.

CARLSON: Any one?

JAYAPAL: Well, you look at Canada. They have a very substantial family- based immigration system. They allow a lot of refugees and immigrants in. And there are different systems all over the world.

CARLSON: Congresswoman, I'm sorry, we're out of time. Just give you one more sentence.

JAYAPAL: I will quote Lindsey Graham to you, Republican senator, America is an idea and we can't cut legal immigration.

CARLSON: American is an idea? No. America is actual people. It's not a theory. I live here. I'm American. I'm not an idea. I am a person.

JAYAPAL: I think the idea of who we are and what we bring with our diversity and people all over the country, all over the world -

CARLSON: That's a decision Americans can make. I appreciate it, congresswoman, for you coming on. Thank you.

JAYAPAL: Thank you.

CARLSON: Hillary Clinton's worldwide excuses tour just made a stop at Georgetown. Her latest explanation is so awesome. Miss it at your peril.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Many of you who've read my book about what happened know that, I think, that misogyny and sexism was part of that campaign. It was one of the contributing factors. And some of it was old-fashioned sexism and a refusal to accept the equality of women and certainly the equality of women's leadership.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: So, even though the majority of married women voted for Trump, all women lost when Hillary did. That, of course, was Hillary Clinton in Georgetown University just yesterday blaming sexism for her 2016 defeat, which apparently is still top of mind.

The remarks come just days after she was denounced for tolerating sexual harassment on her very own campaign team. Blaming people is Hillary Clinton's primary public pastime for the past year. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CLINTON: The use of my email account was turned into the biggest scandal since lord knows when.

I was on the way to winning until a combination of Jim Comey's letter on October 28th and Russia and WikiLeaks raised doubts in the minds of people who were inclined to vote for me, but got scared off.

If you look at Facebook, the vast majority of the news items posted were fake.

There's all these stories about guys over in Macedonia who are running these fake new sites.

He certainly interfered in our election. And it was clearly interfered to hurt me and to help my opponent.

There was voter suppression. People trying to prevent other Americans from being able to vote.

I also think I was the victim of a very broad assumption I was going to win.

I inherit nothing from the Democratic Party.

Look, I take responsibility for every decision I make, but that's not why I lost.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: it's possible it's easier to find public appearances by Hillary Clinton that don't involve blaming everyone in every place from Manhattan to Macedonia. We haven't found one yet.

Brit Hume is Fox's senior political analyst and he joins us tonight. Nothing makes me feel more sympathetic to Hillary Clinton, Brit, than appearances like this because I think this is someone who has no one in her life who can pull her back and tell her how she's coming off to other people.

BRIT HUME, FOX NEWS SENIOR POLITICAL ANALYST: Tucker, she reminds me of other prominent people I've known who have made a terrible mistake, had a big failure, run into trouble.

And they have a very hard time, some of them, owning up to it and admitting that they were involved in a colossal failure and they are to blame because when you think about her failure here, her failure to win this particular election, she was up against Donald Trump, a man who's favorable ratings were deep underwater throughout virtually the entire campaign, the electoral college math appeared to favor her overwhelmingly, the polls all said she was leading and it didn't seem possible she could lose, and yet she did.

That is a very, very hard thing to face up to. And I think she is doing her best to find a way to look at this and a way to frame it that makes it appear that she really wasn't all to blame.

And otherwise, I don't know what she'd do if she didn't have this crutch she has developed of all sorts of other reasons.

CARLSON: I mean, not to turn this into a Bible study or anything, and you've lived a long time, and don't you think it's true that when you accept blame for things, when you realize your failures are your fault, it's liberating. It's good for you. You feel better when you do that.

HUME: Yes. I agree with that. Every now and again, I will get asked to make a graduation speech and my message is always the same to young people. Own your mistakes. Admit them, first of all, to yourself and then to anyone else that might be involved.

And it is liberating. And the peculiar fact of it is that, contrary to how it might feel to you, it almost always ends up making people think better of you than less.

CARLSON: Yes.

HUME: But I think in her case, the burden of this is so great and the burden of acknowledging that, in any end, it was really up to her to get out and win the election and she failed to do so against a candidate who looked like he couldn't possibly win. So, here we are.

I will also say, by the way, Tucker, with regard to those most recent remarks, the ones she made yesterday, I don't think it's the case that America isn't ready for a female leadership and for a woman president.

They were just - the country turned out not to be ready for this woman to be president.

CARLSON: Of course.

HUME: Remember, she turned out not to be, as she refuses to admit, a very effective candidate and she comes with tremendous baggage, which she's always been hesitant to recognize as well, going back to her days in Arkansas and right through her husband's presidency and beyond.

CARLSON: I mean, the obvious lesson in last election is America's pretty open minded. Certainly, open-minded enough to elect the right woman, I would say.

Brit, thank you very much. It's great to see you.

HUME: You bet, Tucker.

CARLSON: Big tech companies know almost everything about you, but they want to know more. We will show you Google's plans to spy on your children - for real - next.

CARLSON: We've been telling you for months now about the growing power of the big tech companies whose brand of surveillance capitalism has come to shape our politics and culture, in ways many people don't perceive.

Tonight, we want to give you a very specific example of that. It's both a look into the near future and a terrifying illustration of the control these companies seek over our daily lives.

We recently reviewed several patents filed by Google. As we describe them, ask yourself if you are comfortable giving this much power to unelected technocrats you have never met.

In the first patent filed in September 2016, Google envisions how it could send you personalized advertising based on what a camera observes in your home.

In the illustration that Google submitted to the federal government, the patent office, a camera in your bedroom sees a "Godfather" novel on your nightstand next to your bed and uses that to steer you to watching the movie.

If you think that's creepy, prepare yourself because it gets a lot creepier. In another patent application from September 2016, Google imagines how it could take control of your parenting, your relationship with your children.

Google's Smart Home system could detect children in your liquor cabinet, for example, or in their parent's bedroom infer that "mischief is occurring and deliver a verbal warning."

In another example, Google imagines a hypothetical child called Benjamin. Google's cameras would be watching Benjamin at all times carefully. They could see if he's playing outside or using electronics.

Presumably, they'll also try to use that information to sell him things at some point because that's the whole point of Google. The same patent also discusses how the Smart Home could coach families on "areas of improvement."

For example, if a family doesn't spend enough time together, eating together, in Google's estimation, Google might scold them and suggest that they set a goal of eating more often together. That is Google's description, not ours, by the way.

We contacted Google for a comment on this and the company. And we're assuming it was a person and not a robot, replied this way. "We file patent applications on a variety of ideas that our employees come up with. Some of those idea later mature into real products or services. Some don't."

In other words, don't worry. We are not spying on you. Yet. We just have the patent for it.

Of course, tech is also dangerous because it's deeply addictive. In fact, more than anything, it's deeply addictive. Now, a group of early Google and Facebook employees are teaming up to check the companies they helped create.

Tristan Harris is a former Google employee. He heads up this new group, the Center for Humane Technology. Jim Steyer is the founder of Common Sense Media, which advocates for children. And they join us tonight. Thank you, both, for coming tonight.

You described these products as addictive. What do you mean by that?

TRISTAN HARRIS, FORMER GOOGLE DESIGNER: Well, what most people don't realize, they see addiction and they think it's happening by accident. We are addicted to lots of things.

We worried about our kids in the 1970s, they were addicted to gossiping on the telephone. What this misses is that, today, behind the other side of the screen when you're using it, there is 100 engineers whose entire job, not because they are evil, but their jobs is to figure out how do I keep you coming back to the product.

So, YouTube wants to autoplay the next video. Snapchat wants to put the number of days in a row, in something called a streak, next to every single person in your kid's contacts. They say, if you've got 30 friends, they say, here is the number days in a row you've sent a message to each friend.

And it keeps each of them hooked, because the business model, so long as it's advertising, is how do I hold on to your attention because the entire stock price is one-to-one linked with how much attention I get. And that's the problem.

CARLSON: So, we know, Jim, screen time has huge consequences.

JIM STEYER, CEO, COMMON SENSE: Huge consequences.

CARLSON: And it hurts children.

STEYER: Correct. It can.

CARLSON: It can. And there are a lot of disturbing metrics about kids and young adults are doing and some of them are linked to tech use. So, why has there been no public recognition of this? No widespread -

STEYER: It's interesting because I run Common Sense, the biggest kids' media group in the country. It has taken time.

I think part of it is we've got so excited about the incredible technological innovations that Silicon Valley brought us. And they are amazing.

We are not anti-tech. Tristan worked at Google. We are not anti-tech at all. Common Sense helps you find the good stuff.

But there has, clearly, been no regulation whatsoever. There's not even at the - no real discussion. And I think what's happening - you are a dad just like I am. My kids are starting to go, I'm not sure I really want this in my life all the time. I don't want this constantly pinging me or wanting me to come there.

Tristan told you what addiction is, but 60 percent of kids in the United States believe they are addicted to their cell phones. That's a really big deal.

CARLSON: So, you worked in them. Are they aware? They must be aware. You're saying they design this to be addictive. Do they have moral qualms about this?

HARRIS: Actually, in 2013, I created a presentation. It was the first Google memo - the second one got really famous - saying we have a moral responsibility as Google because, no matter what we do, we'll bump our elbow and a billion people's attention goes that way or you bump your elbow and a billion people's attention goes that way.

So, how do you ethically steer 2 billion people, actually, their thoughts, when they look at a smartphone or a feed? Because from the moment we wake up in the morning to the 150 times we check per day, it's like it's never been easier to see as a kid. You wake up. You check your phone and you see photo after photo of your friends having fun without you. Is that how we want to ethically care for all these millions and millions of kids?

CARLSON: Do you think, Jim, that there are enough people at these companies who can see clearly enough to pull back from this a little bit?

STEYER: The key is at the top. Here's the deal. Tristan is a whistleblower. This is the cigarette case all over again.

CARLSON: Yes, I agree.

STEYER: We were just with a group of his engineering colleagues who had come forward and say, enough is enough. We've got to tell you this was unintentional. So, the key is the leadership at the top.

I should tell you this is a major challenge now to the people at the very top of the key tech companies in the United States. What values do you have? Is it just about how much money you can make and how much attention - how much the arms race of attention you could win, so you can monetize it by selling ads? Or are there other values?

And by the way, this is not a partisan issue, by the way. Everybody as a parents knows this all across the country.

CARLSON: And it's kind of wrecking the society. And I think we all feel that way.

STEYER: How do you hold them accountable?

CARLSON: I couldn't be rooting for you guys more. Really Godspeed. I hope you come back anytime.

STEYER: We will.

CARLSON: Please do. Thank you. Thank you.

HARRIS: Good to see you, Tucker.

CARLSON: We've got another exclusive report on Google coming tomorrow. Pretty shocking actually. We're going to show you in detail how the company is tracking you without your knowledge. We tested it today.

#MeToo is coming to junk food. Pepsi CEO just speculated on ways that Doritos could be more family friendly. Is it time for some feminist chips? We will meet a feminist chip eater next.

CARLSON: Well, we're not even allowed to have separate bathrooms for men and women anymore, but now we may have separate snack foods. In an interview, the CEO of PepsiCo Indra Nooyi suggested that Doritos could be more female friendly.

The female-friendly version would have a softer crunch and less cheesy residue on the fingers. Well, the comments sparked a backlash on social media, as everything does, which forced Pepsi to clarify today that there are no plans for women-specific Doritos.

Cathy Areu is breathing a sigh of relief. She's founding publisher of "Catalina Magazine" and, of course, spirit guide to the dark recesses of the left. Cathy, it's great to see you tonight.

CATHY AREU, FOUNDING PUBLISHER, "CATALINA MAGAZINE": Thanks. Good to see you.

CARLSON: So, I'm trying to parse - (INAUDIBLE) thinking about what's upsetting about ladies-specific Doritos? And my only conclusion would be they suggest that there is some inherent difference between men and women, which I think is illegal now? Right?

AREU: No, what's upsetting is they were saying that women are different than men in the way that they eat, that women would like to crunch and they would like to lick their fingers when they Doritos, but they don't because women don't feel comfortable in society doing these things.

So, for Doritos, to even think that way, to think we do not want to crunch in public, they want to silent us, that's completely wrong. They are trying to silence women by not letting them crunch in public.

CARLSON: No, that's right. Keep the crunch. So, what's your saying is that vulgarity and rudeness are feminist victories. So, if a woman took her Cheeto paste and rubbed it through her hair or belched at the table, those would be feminist victories, right?

AREU: A feminist victory would be women allowed to do what men do with their Doritos. So, if men are licking their fingers and women should be allowed to do so as well. And the CEO was saying that women don't do those things. Don't feel comfortable doing those things, but want to do those things and to allow them to enjoy their Doritos, they were going to create lady-friendly Doritos.

CARLSON: So, you think - but just to be totally clear - it's a good thing, it's a victory for the feminist ideal when women are as repulsive as men are. Would you dip tobacco ever? Do you think throwing a dip of Copenhagen - do you think, a man does this, I'm doing this?

AREU: Why do you get to be gross and we can't be gross? So, it is a victory when women can be equal to men in any way. So, yes, in the 1700s, women couldn't walk on the grass because it was seen as dirty, but men could walk on the grass. So, it's the same concept. You can lick your fingers, but we can't? So, why do we have to be so pure and clean in society.

CARLSON: Look, I'm not imposing my values on anyone. I'm just wondering where these rules come from.

AREU: Men.

CARLSON: I suspect, as I often suspect when you and I talk, that a lot of these rules are actually formulated and enforced by women, just a guess, having lived here for 48 years. But do you think there's any truth in that?

AREU: It's men. Men are running things, aren't they? Aren't men still considered the majority, even though men are the majority in numbers in the country? Men are the majority, women are the minority. And the majority makes up the rules.

CARLSON: Right.

AREU: And since -

CARLSON: But what if women were actually the majority, which they are, would they change the calculation?

AREU: Women are the majority. Unfortunately, still making $0.77 to every white man's dollar.

CARLSON: And even if that statistic were totally untrue? Before we get into more fake statistics -

AREU: - from the Department of Labor, that's not true.

CARLSON: Yes, yes. OK. But let me ask you this. Do female-specific products always bother you? Does it bother you that bras are for sale? Those are mostly bought by women? Does that feel like a slap in the face to women or eye shadow?

AREU: No. Products that women need - no, there's nothing wrong with those products, but there's no need to make a chip that doesn't let us dirty our fingers. That's what this product is saying.

But men buy eye shadow. It's OK. It's 2018. Men are buying the same products that women are buying.

CARLSON: OK. Does it bother you that women's razors are pink?

AREU: Well, women's razors can be blue as well.

CARLSON: OK. Last question. When you are having dinner out with friends, whatever, non-determined gender, doesn't matter. Do you ever think to yourself, I'm going to be disgusting? I'm going to eat with my hands. I'm going to drink the soup from the bowl just as a way to express your liberation as a woman? Do you ever do that?

AREU: If you can do that and get away with it, but, unfortunately, women, we're just not there yet. And Doritos and PepsiCo doesn't think we're there yet. So, we're not allowed to be disgusting.

CARLSON: Do you ever fold your pizza by putting a finger in the middle like a roll your own cigarette and kind of fold it and just eat it like that? Have you ever Big Mac in fewer than three bites?

AREU: Yes. If I want to be equal and treated equally, I think I will start doing that in public.

CARLSON: You're a feminist, Cathy Areu! I love that about you. Thank you for coming on tonight.

AREU: Thanks.

CARLSON: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau just did some mansplaining about sexism to a woman! It's getting weird in Canada! Details next.

CARLSON: Well, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau isn't just a case of nepotism gone wild, though. Of course, he is. Before using his father's name to take power, Trudeau was a drama teacher and apparently still can't resist the urge to lecture people.

During a recent town hall, Trudeau interrupted a woman and corrected her for using the sinister sexist word mankind.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Maternal love is the love that's going to change the future of mankind.

JUSTIN TRUDEAU, PRIME MINISTER OF CANADA: We like to say peoplekind, not necessarily mankind. It's more inclusive.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: There we go. Exactly. Yes, thank you. We can all learn from each other.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: We can all learn from each other. Of course, Trudeau can't win in this modern world PC that he helped create. Feminists have already denounced him for mansplaining. Of course, the revolution always eats itself. That's the good part.

That's about it for us tonight. Tune in every night at 8:00 to the show that's the sworn enemy of lying, pomposity, smugness and essentially groupthink, which in profound supply these days. DVR it if you haven't already.

Good night from Washington. Sean Hannity is next. Hey, Sean.
